The Roman architect Vitruvius said that architecture includes order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He also gave Greek words for some of these ideas. His definitions likely came from earlier Greek writers whose works we no longer have. Vitruvius did not include utility and function in his definition, but he later explained how to design buildings for different purposes. At first, he focused on the beauty of architecture as an art. The beginnings of classical architecture are complicated. There was a long history of simple buildings, like huts, in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Even though these early structures were not artistic, they still contributed important elements that influenced later architectural designs. In essence, a classical temple, no matter how grand it looks, is based on the simple idea of a single-roomed hut.

Lily and her sister Mui kept a secret from Chen. Lily was learning to drive. She drove around the gardens and the railway, even going over a small bridge. Chen found out and was happy. He said, "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" Mui thought it was strange that Chen was not upset. He was excited and made plans with Lily to go for a drive on a Monday next month. They wanted to leave early and come back by noon so they would not lose any customers. Lily would practice driving before then.
Mui bought a road map, which made Chen happy because she got a discount. But Lily felt a bit insulted because she thought she could find the way herself. Soon, they were at the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat, agreed. Lily passed some slow cars, and Chen clapped for her. 
They drove through the town and parked in a quiet street near the sea. Lily was not sure about the parking signs, so she decided to pay to avoid problems. She locked the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "No one will want that old van." The sisters were not happy with his joke. 
Chen took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. Man Kee was a warm and happy baby. Chen thought about how he would raise Man Kee. He wanted him to learn about business and own restaurants one day. The sea made Chen feel thoughtful. 
He saw a ship far away and used a telescope to look at it. At first, he could not find it, but then he did. It was a small, old ship. Chen lifted Man Kee to see it. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked. "It is a special ship for us. It will take us back home one day." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. 
Lily and Mui were behind them. Lily put her arm around Chen. Chen said, "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee did not want to give up the telescope. When he finally did, the view was not clear anymore. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and Lily could only see seagulls flying.

**THE WELL**
I read somewhere that if you dig a deep hole, you can see the stars when it is clear. I asked you to help me with my idea. You watched with wide eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle while I pushed the bucket off the wall. I fell into the well. I hit my head. At first, I saw strange lights. Later, I remembered how cartoon characters see stars when they get hit on the head. 
At that moment, I felt confused, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say. You called down to me, asking if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I stopped. I lay still and watched you through my eyelashes. You ran away to get help. I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge. I landed on the courtyard stones. I heard loud voices from the castle door. I ran away to hide in the shadows. 
My mother and father came with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming. My father told Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You looked pale and shocked. I was hiding in the shadows, feeling excited. Then I saw the drops of dirty water I had left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the dry stones. I looked back at my father, who was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. My mother was screaming loudly now, a sound I had never heard before. It scared me. 
What should I do? I had played a trick on you, but now it was serious. It went from a fun idea to something that could get me in big trouble. I was angry with myself for not thinking this through. I thought of a plan. I gathered my courage and came out of hiding. I cried out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a little and then fell on the stones. I sat up, feeling comforted in my mother’s arms. I said I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat and crawled through it until I got out. 
I thought I was almost getting away with it until my father came to me. He asked me to repeat my story. I did, but I hesitated. His eyes narrowed. I said the secret passage had fallen in after me, and it was dangerous to go down. I looked into my father’s eyes, and it felt like looking into a dark tunnel. He said, “Don’t be ridiculous, boy,” with a tone that made me feel very small. He walked away. Arthur looked at me with a sad expression, shaking his head. He could see through my lie and worried about me. This made me feel even worse.

**Removal Day**
Susan is a widow. Her children are now grown up, and she has to leave her family home. A van with the words "Removers of Distinction" is outside. Fred, the removal man, is packing her things carefully. He is big and strong, and he is careful with the fragile items. Susan's house is beautiful. It has four floors and looks over a small harbour. She remembers the years she spent there with her children. 
When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five years old, asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" Now, Robert is helping her move, and he is making sure she does not talk about the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is very bossy and wants to take care of the piano because it is special.
Fred notices that Susan is not crying. He tells her that some people cry when they move. They are happy while packing, but when they see the empty house, they start to cry. Susan understands this feeling. She thinks she should have told the movers about the piano before they started.
The piano is in the best room of the house. They will move it last. Sitting on the stairs, Susan remembers the day they moved in. The piano was the first thing they brought into the house, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers worked hard for two hours to get it inside. Robert watched with excitement, and Francesca cried because she wanted the piano in the house.
Peter, Susan's late husband, helped solve the problem. They had to take out a window to get the piano inside. A crane was used to lift it through the window, and the children were very happy to see it. It took a long time to save money to tune the piano after that.
Now, Susan feels sad. Her children are busy and do not come home often. She is also having trouble moving around the house. She worries about the piano and thinks she should have told the movers about it. 
Fred asks if she is okay. He tells her that the piano is the last thing to move. Susan's heart is racing. Robert and Francesca come to watch. Fred talks to her, and she feels like crying. Moving things makes her think about how important they are. 
Just then, the piano comes down the stairs. Fred is careful with it. They take it outside and put it down by the van. Robert laughs first, and soon they are all laughing together. They are happy that the move is over. As they walk down the path for the last time, Susan only sheds tears of laughter.

Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**
**Do-it-yourself literary criticism: Is it just fun?**
The Internet was made to be open for everyone. This means anyone can share their ideas or create a music channel online. At first, you needed some technical skills to do this, but there was one area that became open to many people: book reviews. 
Amazon.com was the first popular online bookstore. Here, anyone could write a review about a book and give it up to five stars. This was a great idea because it allowed readers to see what others thought about a book, not just what the publisher said or what professional critics wrote. 
Other online bookstores also allowed reviews, but Amazon was the biggest. It had more than 80% of the online market and received many reviews. However, this also led to some problems. Thousands of reviews were sent every day, and Amazon could not check them all. They had a team of editors who looked for reviews that broke the rules, like one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors. But many reviews were still anonymous, so it was easy for some people to write fake reviews.
For example, a writer named Lev Grossman was upset by bad reviews of his first book. He wrote some good reviews under a fake name to make his book look better. This worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed his fake reviews. 
Authors could also comment on their own books by clicking a link. Most authors wrote friendly messages asking people to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses for readers to contact them. However, Amazon did not always check if the comments were really from the authors, except for famous writers.
One time, a little-known writer pretended to be famous author John Updike in a comment. Amazon quickly removed it because it was fake. 
The real drama happened with reader reviews. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team came out, it got good reviews from the press. But some people mentioned in the book were angry and wrote many bad reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days. 
Despite this, Amazon liked that many people were writing and reading reviews. They wanted reviews to be a place to talk about books, not just a chat room. They paid special attention to popular books to make sure the reviews followed the rules. 
For less popular books, people could post funny reviews. For example, "The Story about Ping," a children's book about a duck, inspired some silly reviews. One review compared the book to how the Internet works. 
Most reviews on Amazon were serious, and they helped people decide if a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that writing too many reviews was hard because you had to pretend to feel something about books you didn’t care about. This is why letting everyone write reviews is a good thing.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last two hundred years, people often say that artists must go against the art of their time. We like to think that art is special, new, and sometimes shocking. We feel good when we admire artists whose work was not liked a hundred years ago. But when we look at art today, we often say that an artist has gone too far or that their work is not really art. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be very different. We forget that today’s art has old ideas and methods too. 
In the past, people asked artists to create art for specific reasons, and art was part of everyday life. Now, we let artists work alone and sometimes get upset if they do not connect with us.
**Picture This**
I will describe a situation and then ask an important question. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about different kinds of pictures and asks, "What are they all about?" It then says, "There are many different kinds of pictures." This is simple language, but stay with me. 
After choosing the text, the artist asks someone to make a canvas for him. He tells a sign painter to write the text on the canvas in simple black letters without making it fancy. The sign painter does this. My important question is: Is this finished work a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26, there is a rule that successful painters should stick to one style. Collectors want artists to keep making the same kind of art, and if they try something new, people often feel disappointed. 
Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, can change their style and still be successful. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something new. He is moving from painting still lifes to painting the London Underground. He finds the underground interesting. His new show, called Underground Encounters, has 40 paintings and drawings that show the magic of this hidden world where people travel.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. I say "escape" because the villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a quiet place to live. I am here to heal myself. I am alone except for an old woman who comes from the village to clean my house. I feel neither happy nor sad; I feel like I am floating in my memories. 
I talked about the uselessness of art but did not say how it can comfort us. The comfort of art is that it helps us see reality in a new way. Our everyday actions often hide the true meaning of life. For artists, art helps us deal with the pain of daily life and fulfill our imagination. Otherwise, why should we hurt each other?

**Family Business**
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I got a prize for Latin and another prize for doing well in my exams. He had talked a lot with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, but I already knew what he was thinking because he was quiet. My father usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I replied, trying to act brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. "I just said that," I said. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality. You can understand a lot of information quickly, you are good at talking, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."
"Anyway," he said, "I feel like you won't want to join the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to do it."
The problem was that I felt trapped by what my family expected. I could see many jobs I could do, and I wanted to explore them. But I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was his favorite - but I still found him strong.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you won't want to join us," said my father, who often turned out to be right. "It's a pity because you have the skills - the brains, the courage, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling unhappy. My father laughed. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business.
"Anyway," I said, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and I took care of him because he didn't have a mother. I loved Maurice. 
Because the business was successful, we lived well - in a big house in London, nice schools, good clothes, parties, and shows. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, and businesspeople - and our house was always busy with interesting conversations.
"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford. Then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to avoid making choices right now, especially because my father would be sad if I disagreed. This was how he controlled us.
So, I helped out during my last term at school and during university vacations, never more than twice a year and always with easier tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a small house, a nice car, and good clothes.
In my last term, my father came to see me and took me to a village for a meal. There were only a few weeks left. My teacher said I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I wanted to focus on studying.
My father told me that he needed me to do one last important job for the family business. "But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon, and I need to focus on that. It's really important."
I could see that my father didn't understand how important my exams were. He would think that if I said no, I was being unkind. As he explained the job, I saw how focused and strong he was. He was very good at his work, and I admired that. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year after he and Lois moved in. It was a big expense that they could only afford by being very careful with their money. At first, it seemed like a good idea. Simon had many successful cases at work, and Lois returned to her job at the advertising agency two months after their twins were born. She got a raise, and her salary was thirty-five thousand.
Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for their family. They needed more space, a garden, and a separate room for an au pair. They could have found a bigger place in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted to live in a nice part of London. She thought that living in a less fashionable place would not look good for Simon, who was a young barrister, and for her as a successful businesswoman.
Lois decided that one of them should take public transport to save money. Since her office was far away, Simon had to take the tube. The crowded journey made him feel unhappy and angry. He thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he stayed as a boy. He remembered the smell of dinner and how his grandmother took care of his grandfather when he came home tired from work. She was always at legal events and seemed happy with her life.
Lois made it clear before they got married that her job was just as important as Simon's. They both needed their salaries to pay for the house and their lifestyle. Now, they were worried that a woman named Venetia could ruin everything. Venetia had come to their office in a bad mood. She was very angry about something.
Simon wished he had left his room earlier to avoid talking to her. He remembered her angry words. She accused him of knowing that a man named Brian Cartwright had bribed jurors four years ago when Simon was his lawyer. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty. He remembered feeling scared when he was a boy and got in trouble at school.
When he looked into Venetia's eyes, he saw that she did not believe him. He wished he had said something different to defend himself. He thought about how Venetia was judging him and if she had the right to do that. He was worried that if people heard the rumors, it could ruin his career.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would be alone. I wanted to be among people who did not care about broken houses or messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you, even if you don’t know them. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens can be loved. Usually, I stay inside and try to forget about summer, but tonight I am watching the birds flying between the trees and roofs. I have cut back some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are a bit sore from working in the garden. It is a small garden in London, where plants have to grow tall to survive.
“Looks like you are cleaning up,” says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz. She is a writer and I sometimes help her with her work. I have her latest story with me. “How is your writing going, Jaz?” I ask. “Oh, it’s hard. People always ask me about my work,” she replies. “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down.” I don’t want Jaz in the garden, and I see that it looks messy. She knocks on my door. “So, you are on holiday now,” she says, sitting in my chair while I put a cushion on the ground. “I should have become a teacher. Writers don’t have holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do, and those who can’t, teach.” 
“What are your plans for the holiday?” she asks. I feel worried about the empty days ahead. “I am going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?” I ask. “Of course,” Jaz says, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? A nice bed and breakfast?” “No, I will stay with my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun. We have been friends since we were kids.” This is not true, but I often deal with stories.
“Going back to your roots. What do you think of my story?” Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I have not read much. I like the title. I can see how red vans can be cruel, bringing gifts to other houses. I decide to be honest. “Try writing about nice people for a change,” I say. “A little less about yourself and more about others.” “Teachers!” Jaz replies, upset. “I keep a journal where I write something good about each day.” My advice sounds old-fashioned. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” I have a life. I work, go out sometimes, and read on the tube. 
When we go inside, my calm kitchen makes me feel better. Then I remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now. She once winked at us and said, “I’ve had my moments.” We all laughed. 
---
**Questions:**
1. Why did the narrator choose this place to live?
2. What does the narrator usually do during summer?
3. Who is Jaz and what does she do?
4. What does Jaz offer to bring to the narrator?
5. Where is the narrator going tomorrow?
6. What advice does the narrator give to Jaz about her writing?

**Heritage**
Heritage means the connection people have with their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage because we know about our grandparents and have heard stories about their lives. It is important to learn about our past to understand our future. Heritage helps us feel a part of something bigger. It teaches us about our culture and traditions. In the past, people shared stories to keep their heritage alive, but now many of these stories are lost. Instead, we can learn from old buildings and places. It is important to protect these places to remember our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I wrote a novel called *Waterland*, and the Fens, a flat area in England, are important in the story. Some people ask why I wrote about a place I do not know well. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and quiet, but I learned they are actually very interesting and unique. Many people in England find the Fens strange, even though they are part of England. The Fens are both empty and full of life, wild and cultivated, open and mysterious. I have not visited some towns in the Fens, but I like to imagine what they are like. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a way of thinking.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, they just put items in display cases with long labels. Now, museums should be more interesting and use creative ways to attract visitors. They should also help many different people enjoy their collections. For example, some museums lend boxes of objects to teachers and even help elderly people who are losing their memory. Museums show real items from history, not copies. This is their strength. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will attract more visitors who want to see real history.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to keep things safe is not new, but changes in our towns happen quickly. This can make some people want to protect old buildings and encourage others to think about how towns change. People who have lived through big events, like wars, may want to preserve things more than others. If we need to keep things safe, planners should consider this. Change is not bad if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect changes in our society, like our population and needs.

Einstein**
If you ask people on the street to name a scientist, many will say Albert Einstein. His picture is used to sell many products, like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did, except that he created some famous theories called 'relativity'. These theories are known for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that do not match everyday life.
Einstein was part of a big change in science. Scientists wanted to understand the universe better by studying how matter and natural forces work together. Einstein made important contributions by looking closely at basic ideas: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists like Isaac Newton thought that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but can change.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I did not like prize-winning books because we thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this and often showed her disapproval. But our father would give us small coins for each chapter we read to encourage us. He also gave us some special books for Christmas and birthdays, marked with 'This Book is NOT Literature'. We thought many of his books were for boys, but he did help us read some good stories and even a famous book of poems.
**Language**
Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the beginning of human language is a secret and wonderful thing. This secret has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller said in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. Early humans who faced dangerous animals made desperate noises, and some words today still remind us of this, like "malaria" meaning "fever" and the Latin word "mors" meaning "death".
Many people thought these ideas were silly, but now, the study of how language began and changed is very important. Language likely started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech for friendly talks and to gain power. Sharing information was probably not the main reason for language, which is different from what philosopher John Locke said about language being a way to share knowledge.

Writing Reviews**
Frank Kermode talks about writing reviews. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. They have deadlines and must be short. When they are published, they are only in the newspaper for a day, a week, or maybe a month. Because of this, many people think that writing reviews is not very important. Some believe that people only write reviews because they need money. Others think it is because they cannot spend all their time on a book.
However, writing reviews is a skilled job. It is different to write a short review of 600 or 800 words than to write a longer review of 6,000 or 8,000 words. A good reviewer must think about who will read the review. Some readers just want a quick summary, while others want a detailed analysis.
A reviewer needs to know a lot about different topics and must write in a way that is easy for smart people to understand. Most reviewers also write other things besides reviews. For example, the American writer John Updike does some reviewing while he writes his novels. He collects all his reviews into books with simple titles.
Some people think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last long. But if they believe their best writing is in reviews, they should be allowed to keep them. I feel this way about my own work. I mostly write academic books, which are serious and for professors. In English-speaking countries, it is common for the same people to write both reviews and academic studies.
In the past, some academics did not like professors who wrote reviews. They thought it was a waste of time. But now, there are many reviews, and many people can write them. This is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. It is also good for professors because it helps them remember to write clearly for everyone, not just for other professors.
In conclusion, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a secondary job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph opened the door to his flat. When he entered the dark hall, he felt a quick feeling of ownership. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes came back to him when he returned home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he was always excited to come home. He wondered what the flat had been doing while he was away. It felt like a welcome place for him, a space where he could relax. 
He thought he should worry about things like break-ins or leaks, but his flat always seemed to be waiting for him. It looked either independent or a bit messy, depending on how he had left it. Over time, he started to see it as part of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He became frustrated that it could not change. 
There were always some letters by the door and the answering machine sometimes blinked when he got home. He was thankful that his windows were not broken and that nothing bad had happened to his flat. From his small office on the third floor, Ralph often looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After leaving the busy office, he felt a little more like himself on the bus ride home. 
But when he got home, he didn’t want to be alone anymore. At his desk, he wanted to be by himself, but when he escaped from work, he felt empty. He wondered if working in a job he didn’t like had changed him. He often read or listened to music at night, but he started to ask himself why he did these things. 
His thoughts became unclear, and he felt lost. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and thought he could change his life. But he had wanted something so much that he just followed the first opportunity that came his way. After university, he tried to make a plan for his life, but he only wanted to survive. 
He applied for jobs he heard about from his friends and followed them as they moved ahead. He went to one job interview and was happy to talk with Neil, his future boss. Neil offered him a job right away, saying he was the only graduate who had applied. Ralph took this as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**
I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I was moving through ice-cream vans, many people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was going to the racecourse, but I pushed through the crowds to find a good spot. They had made a special area for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people were standing on both sides of the ground where the goats would run. They were trying to keep a few goats in order. This is not easy because goats can eat almost anything!

As the day ended, I started to worry about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and we could not find a place to stop. We had not seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we could see the cliffs, but our flashlight was not working well. We changed the batteries, but they did not work either. We could not find a place to camp. A little later, Lesley said she saw a light far away, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon shining on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud sound of rushing water, but we could not see what was happening. We kept moving on.
**How to Be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and important shareholders. How can I get better at this and feel more confident? You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company, but many leaders need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask your colleagues what tough questions the audience might ask. You should also create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone can relate to and then move towards your main point.

Some activities take time and cannot be rushed. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient with making mayonnaise and add the oil too fast, it will not work. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, it will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things happen very quickly, while others take a long time, like seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. 
We can get better at some things, like solving puzzles or doing math quickly. But some things cannot be rushed. If we try to hurry them, they can break, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled, like the fishing line. Sometimes, saying "Think fast; we need results" is not helpful. We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds.
There are three main speeds of thinking. The first is very fast. Some situations need a quick reaction. For example, if my motorbike slipped on a wet road, my body moved quickly to keep me safe. I did not think about it; I just reacted. This fast reaction is called our "wits."
The second speed is thinking. This is when we figure things out, weigh options, and solve problems. For example, a mechanic fixing a car or a student working on homework is using this kind of thinking. We often call this "intellect." People who are good at solving problems are called "bright" or "clever."
The third speed is slower. This way of thinking is more relaxed and dreamy. When we sit quietly by the sea or are just about to sleep, we are in this slower thinking mode. This slow thinking is also important. It helps us understand complex situations. 
Recent studies show that taking time to think slowly can help us solve difficult problems. When we are not sure what to do, it is better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This slow thinking is connected to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have known for a long time that slow thinking can be very valuable. Scientists are now studying these slower ways of thinking and finding that they can help us understand many things better. 
**Questions:**
1. What happens if you add oil too quickly when making mayonnaise?
2. What are the three speeds of thinking mentioned in the text?
3. Why is slow thinking important?
4. How can slow thinking help us with difficult problems?
5. Who has known about the value of slow thinking for a long time?

Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I have been welcomed warmly. It is a friendly place in a very isolated area. There are about forty people here - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers. We all work together as a community. My school French is enough to communicate, but not enough to have fun conversations. I miss the small details in conversations, and my phrasebook does not help me at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt unsure of myself. I was a little scared of mealtimes. I would wait and worry about which table to sit at. I felt anxious, like I did in the first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or feel nervous when people talk to me. I think this feeling is not about missing people or communication, but about losing my confidence in social situations.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was just a young writer, and he did not notice me. He remembered faces, and when I saw him, he would shake my hand but did not want to be friends. If I saw him at the opera with important people, he would not see me. But then I became successful as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to be friendlier. One day, he sent me a note to have lunch, and I thought he wanted to get to know me better. After that, I met him more often because my success brought me new friends.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
The film director Alfred Hitchcock said he did not care about the story of his films or the acting. He cared about the pictures and the sound. For Hitchcock, it was not the message or the acting that moved the audience. He believed that people react to the film itself, no matter where they come from. So, if a film is made well, people in Japan and India should react at the same time. Hitchcock was very clear and logical about his work. He was a genius who liked to see the audience react. He did not think about deep ideas or complex meanings. He focused on the film and how it could affect the audience.

Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good, and there were few practical guides. Today, we have many types of telescopes and equipment available. Electronic calculators and computers help us make charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomy. 
However, some things are worse now. People may need to travel 80 km to find a dark sky, which was easier to find 50 years ago. During the day, we see many airplane trails in the sky. These trails can last for hours and make it hard to see the sun and stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, we have too many choices. There are many things to do and many products to buy. People want the newest things, and technology makes this faster. New products come out all the time, and it can be overwhelming. More choices can cause stress and take up our time. 
Because of this, many people want to simplify their lives. They look for simple things that make them happy in a complicated world. But it is not easy to simplify life when there are so many products and options available.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, my family stays for two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother. It is very important to us. We do not want anything to change this tradition. 
The guests at McAndrews Hotel are often old-fashioned. I do not like the bad manners of some shop assistants today. I prefer to be polite and keep my distance from others. I know many of the other guests because we have been coming here since we were children. When I see them, we usually just say hello and do not talk much. This respect for privacy is hard to find in hotels today.

Othello and Lake Vostok**
**Othello**  
A great show of Shakespeare's play Othello is now in London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the show started last spring. I said that Ray Fearon was too young for the main role, and I did not like his acting. I still think it is not right to change the age difference between Othello and Desdemona, but I take back my words about Mr. Fearon's great performance. The whole cast is wonderful. Some memorable scenes are when Cassio plays games with other young officers, and things go too far. Another important moment is when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very emotional. The speed and tension in the play are amazing. Do not miss this show!
**Lake Vostok**  
In Antarctica, there is very little life. On the edges, you can see penguins, seals, and birds. But in the middle, there is a huge area of ice with no life. However, there is a big hidden lake called Lake Vostok under almost 4 kilometers of ice. This lake has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are excited to explore this lake and find out what strange life might be there. For two years, researchers from around the world have been trying to learn the secrets of the lake. If they succeed, we will see many discoveries about Lake Vostok in the next few years.
**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. Some scientists are thinking about why they want to be scientists. We know they want to learn about everything, from tiny atoms to big black holes. But these scientists want to understand why we want to know these things. They wonder why science cannot explain this desire. I think it is more important to know if what scientists do is right, rather than argue about why we want to know. Science is a tool, and we should decide how and when to use it.

Food and People**
**Food**  
Food is very important in our lives. Many people who like cooking buy cookbooks. Sometimes, we think cooking is only for special occasions or fancy dishes. But that is not true! You can make a tasty soup by putting chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and some herbs in water. This is better than buying soup in a packet or a can. Instead of buying a sweet chocolate dessert full of chemicals, you can make a delicious treat in just five minutes. Cooking is also a way to show care and love. Sharing food is special, and we often celebrate important events like birthdays and anniversaries with meals. No one would want to eat takeout at a wedding!
**In the Elevator**  
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but it was still messy. Papers were everywhere, and he had many tax forms to organize. He also had a lot of books and journals. As he took the elevator to his floor, he knew Mallory would arrive on time for their meeting. She was very punctual and liked things to be neat. He wondered how she would react to the mess. She might think someone had made a mess in his office. Alistair saw his cleaning lady, Mrs. Wilson, and smiled at her. But she looked unhappy and did not want to go into his messy office.
**Karen**  
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She created her own story about strength. One important moment in her life was when she was twelve years old. Her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she would go blind. But the doctor said she was okay and only needed a few stitches. When she saw her mother in the doctor's office, her mother talked about miracles. Karen felt she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**  
Miss Fogerty was walking quickly across the village green. She felt both excited and sad about something she had just seen. It is nice to be the first to know important news in a small town, but she was also worried about Dr. Bailey's health. He had been her doctor for many years and always cared for her when she was sick. She appreciated how he took the time to listen to her problems. This made him very loved in the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor to his patients, and they respected him for it.

**Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She plays music for many people. But she also writes books for young children who want to learn the piano. Joanna plays the piano very well. She can play many types of music, like classical, jazz, and blues. One time, at a concert for kids, a small boy asked her, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This surprised her, but she thought it was funny. She played it for him, and he was happy.
Joanna cares a lot about how children learn to play the piano. She has written a book called *Joanna MacGregor's Piano World* to help kids learn. Even though she is very busy with concerts and other projects, she wanted to make this book. She believes that the first lessons in music are very important. Many people think only about the best musicians, but Joanna thinks everyone should be able to enjoy music.
When she was younger, Joanna taught many children how to play the piano. She remembers how much fun it was to play music with them. She wants all kids to have the chance to learn the piano, just like they can learn to swim or speak a little French. Some kids learn quickly, but others take more time and sometimes give up. Joanna worries that some children stop playing because they feel too much pressure from their parents to be perfect.
Joanna does not want to criticize other piano books or teachers. She knows her books are not the only ones that can help kids learn. Her books have stories and music to make learning fun. She believes that children should enjoy playing the piano. They should be able to play freely and try new things.
As children learn, they need to practice reading music. Joanna understands that this can be hard. She thinks practice is very important. She did not practice a lot until she went to music school, but now she loves it. She practices for many hours every day. Joanna wants to help children who find practicing difficult. She suggests that they set goals for their practice and mix easy pieces with harder ones. 
Learning music should be fun, and Joanna wants to make sure all children can enjoy it.

Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said that "what is written without effort is usually read without pleasure." This means that good writing is hard to do. When I look at my old school essays, I see that I did not cross out many words. Today, I would change my writing many times. I think this is because writing by hand is hard. Writing slowly helps me think better. When I write on a computer, I can change things easily, but this can make my writing careless. 
Many writers spend a lot of time fixing their work on a computer, just like they would if they wrote by hand. Also, emails are different from handwritten letters. Emails can be quick and not very emotional. But many people now write love letters in emails. This is good because at least they are writing in English and using some grammar. However, words on a screen can feel boring. People often do not think carefully about what they write, and their messages can become confusing. 
One day, I looked at a CD. The case was not very nice, but the shiny disc inside looked interesting. Mr. Warriston came into the room and said, "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" I agreed and gave him the disc. He said, "It is amazing that they can fit seventy minutes of music on them." He turned on the music player, and lights came on. He put the disc inside and pressed a button. 
I asked, "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" He said, "No, you only play one side." I wondered why. He thought for a moment and said, "I don't know. You could make both sides playable." He smiled and said, "Good point." Then he told me to sit in the best place to hear the music.
**Books vs. Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said that if matches were invented after cigarette lighters, we would think matches were old and not good. Some people say that electronic text is as important as the invention of printing. They think it will change everything. But it takes a long time for people to change how they think. 
In 1979, a book said that books would slowly disappear in the 1980s. This was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is not enjoyable, so many people do not do it. Computers make it easy to read only parts of a text. Some people say this is good because it creates new ways to tell stories. But many books have always been read in parts, like religious texts and dictionaries. The problem is that computers do not help people read everything from start to finish.
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office and saw everything was neat. The carpet was clean, and the desk was dark wood, just like he remembered. Files were in their right places, and twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves. Kathleen was trying to close a filing cabinet and then looked at him. 
"You have to use computers, Charles. This is too much," she said. 
"Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he replied, looking at the room and its old furniture. He did not think about computers at all. They had talked about this many times before. She did not understand why he did not want to use technology, even though he was good with computers and had written an important paper about them. She could use software to create new things easily.

"You don’t take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She was not really asking; she was stating a fact because she had been making coffee for Lancelot for many months. She forgot sometimes because he was not usually there. But now, he was there all the time. He realized that if he stayed away, things would go wrong. 
He thought about how he had changed from a valued helper, meeting authors and playwrights for lunch, to someone who was always busy and had trouble finding a place to park at work. 
"This came," she yelled, waving a folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." Under that, it said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see "A First Draft." He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one. 
Ian Cuthbert had received a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was one of Lancelot's old friends, and he had made a mistake by asking him to write books. Ian was known for being unpredictable. Lancelot quickly read the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and pushed it aside. It seemed that Ian's manuscript would never come. The synopsis was not as brilliant as it should have been, and it felt like it lacked real ideas. 
Lancelot remembered a famous author who had published an incomplete book after his death. That author had been paid little by little for each chapter. But Ian had received a lot of money upfront, which was not how things should work. Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising talent in Cambridge. Ian's friends wanted to take over British theatre, and they did. But Ian seemed lazy compared to them. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he had met them. 
For some reason, Ian's creative ideas stayed hidden. While others succeeded, Ian did not. Even when he was influential, he was hard to work with. He was supposed to edit a magazine about the arts, but it never got published. His contract with a fashion magazine was renewed three times, but he still did not produce anything. At meetings, he was critical of other people's ideas. Ten years later, he was not reliable at all. Lancelot was starting to think that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the beginning.

England's Breakfast Revolution**
A good breakfast is very important, according to health experts. But in history, breakfast is a new idea in England. In medieval times, people did not often write about breakfast. Some travelers ate a meal at dawn before long journeys, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.
In the sixteenth century, breakfast became normal for more people. Some writers say this happened because there was more food available. However, there were also big changes in society. For example, more people had jobs with set hours. Many of these jobs started very early in the morning. So, eating breakfast became necessary for everyone, not just for rich people.

**Photography**  
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences. This choice is also influenced by social and cultural ideas. In this book, we will see how these factors change the style and meaning of a photograph. We will also look at how people see and react to these images. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they understand the photos in a special way. But instead of just believing what they see, we can ask if the photo shows the scene as it really was. Or, does it show what the photographer thinks? Is the exact moment in the photo important, or does it represent something bigger in the world?
**More than a Game**  
For me, sport is more than just a game. The best athletes believe in themselves completely. To be the best, you need to focus only on your goal. Sport is tough, and no one will do the work for you. You either succeed or fail. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, but it also shows the importance of teamwork. My sport lets me shine as an individual, but it is also a team game, and I must balance both. It is like life – you can do well alone, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened doors for me and shown me things in the world that many people will never see. But you also have to give up a lot to get these rewards.
**Tuning In**  
Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, one special moment happened one night in California a long time ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing from a tree in my neighborhood. I don’t have trouble sleeping, but the beautiful singing kept me awake. As I listened to the bird's songs, I felt like I was in a special musical world. To understand the bird's music, I thought about jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an amazing live performance. I cheered and groaned as the bird sang different tunes through my open window, until I finally fell asleep.

People have always talked a lot about birds. But what does this say about us? Paul Evans writes about it.
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Is it trying to tell us something, or is it just stuck? Depending on how you see it, both could be true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, we still see images of wrens in many British homes. Even if old beliefs are not as strong now, people still care about wrens. A place without wrens feels sad.
This connection with birds comes from a time when people depended on nature for survival. They created stories and meanings about birds. These meanings can change over time. For example, the red kite bird was once seen as a helpful bird in London, taking food from children. But later, people thought of them as pests, and they disappeared from many places. Now, red kites are protected again and are important for conservation in Britain.
Our connection with birds is deep and goes back to when humans first started to notice them. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about who we are. Birds can fly, sing, and represent freedom. Our interest in birds shows something about our own nature.
Some people think our feelings for birds are not important now. But these feelings are still part of us, and losing them would be hard. That is why birds are important for understanding changes in the environment. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because it means we are losing not just birds but also part of our culture. 
Certain birds, like the skylark and turtle dove, represent love and magic. Many poems and stories mention these birds, and losing them makes us feel sad. However, we often ignore the loss of other birds that are not in stories or poems.
Folklore, which includes stories and legends about birds, is very important. These stories connect us to birds in a way that scientific facts do not. They help us feel and understand our world better. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel cannot be explained by science alone. Birds are fascinating, and the stories we tell about them help us understand their meaning in our lives. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a long history, and its song makes us think about the future.

Maps**
A map shows how places and features on the earth are related to each other. This is done by showing distance and direction. In the past, people often talked about distance in terms of time, like "a few hours' walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring distance helped people understand how easy it was to travel in different areas, but it did not give exact distances.
Direction is also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" So, exact directions were not always very important. Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not show true directions.
In the past, important landmarks along a route were marked by signs that could be realistic or simple. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and location. To understand old maps, it is important to know the specific way they were made.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is about how we have become better at showing distance and direction on maps. Over time, cartographers used other sciences to help them. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, they started using compasses and tools to measure angles accurately.
As people explored the world more, they wanted better maps. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, which helped improve maps of large areas. The needs of map users also changed. Soldiers, especially after the invention of cannons, needed accurate maps to understand the land better. This led to the creation of contour maps.
Other people, like archaeologists and historians, also needed maps for their work. Today, cartographers make maps for many different uses, such as showing land use or climate. This shows how important maps are in many fields of study.
It is important to remember that the development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times when map-making did not progress, and old ideas sometimes stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers have often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Since it is easy to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas.
Therefore, we should not always trust maps as the best evidence of what we know today. The many maps we have now are the result of a lot of hard work and thought. They are valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes learning about historical cartography interesting and important.

I met a young man named Andrew Lloyd Webber in his nice room. His room was very different from the messy other rooms in his house. He had many records, a stereo record player, and even nice wine glasses. Andrew was a student at Magdalen College, Oxford, studying history. He had nine months before starting school, and he wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers.
I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like money and fame. But my dreams were not as important as Andrew's. When Andrew asked me to try to be a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I agreed. He played me some of his music, and I thought it was very good.
We decided to work together. I was still more interested in pop music than in musicals, but I knew Andrew was talented. I thought it would be exciting to help him. The next day, I was back at my job training to be a lawyer. I felt less sure about my dreams of show business with Andrew. I thought I would probably become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five, as my father expected.
But I wanted to see Andrew again. It would be fun to write lyrics for musicals. Andrew was interesting; he talked about good food and football. He had an idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, who started orphanages. I thought the story was good, but not very exciting. However, Andrew believed in his music, and I wanted to help him.
I started to write funny songs for the musical. Andrew told me the story and played the music. I even skipped a day at my lawyer job to write lyrics. That day, I didn’t know it, but I was starting a new career.
