**Language**  
You and I are part of a special group of living things. We can share thoughts and feelings with each other using language. Language is very important in our lives. If you see two or more people together, they will probably be talking. When people are alone, they might talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I think of language as a natural skill. This means that people know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders do not need to learn how to spin webs; they just do it.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They have a big effect on animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow. These jungles have many different kinds of plants and animals. In cold and windy places, there are not many living things. The weather changes every day because of big air movements. The air moves because the Earth spins. The sun also helps to move the air.
**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, my job was to serve drinks, but I also had to make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I had several days of training to learn how to make coffee and clean the espresso machine. I learned how to make a good cappuccino. After the first week, I realized that making coffee was harder than it seemed. I thought I might have to do easier tasks again. Luckily, my boss was patient. He said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

Art on TV**
Why does television often have problems with shows about art? Painting and sculpture are good subjects for TV because the camera can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. 
A good example is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would show great artworks, but it focused more on how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a dealer in metals and became known as a speculator. The metals market has fewer rules than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this business. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market economy. 
However, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep the prices of rare metals high have found that the opposite is true. More minerals are being taken from the ground, and the prices of raw materials are going down. If we consider inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to look into claims against a big company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and something special to offer. To get around the islands of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to explore on your own. 
Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the Bamboo Bike Club**
You can build your own bamboo bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by two engineers, James Marr and Ian McMillan. When you join a course, you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and a fun weekend of bike-building.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bamboo bikes. I went to see what was happening. There is a lot of energy and fun in the workshop. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Some companies, like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire, have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. But many cyclists find these bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost about $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes that everyone could afford. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a business. They wanted to share the joy of making something special and sustainable. Now, the Bamboo Bike Club is more about community than just a business. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They run monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price.
On the first day of the course, James and Ian teach how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. They help you glue the bamboo tubes together to make the bike frame. They also use metal tubes for parts that need to be strong, like the handlebars and wheel forks. This can be hard for someone who is not good at DIY. But James and Ian are there to help. They check every cut and joint to make sure everything is right. If you make a mistake, it’s okay. You can just try again with a new piece of bamboo.
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are as strong as metal bikes. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months.
The bamboo bikes may not look as perfect as metal bikes, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that these bikes are meant for a relaxed ride, not for racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a comfortable ride. When I tried James's bike, it felt light and smooth, even on bumpy roads.
James says, "Some people love building the bike, but I think the best part is riding it." The bamboo bikes are fun to ride and cost less than £500.

**Self-help Books**  
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title was great and knew it would be a bestseller. She was right! Now, Dr. Gray is very rich, and Diane has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand each other better, especially men and women. This book is very popular and is part of a big self-help industry in America. This industry helps many people who want to improve their lives. It also makes a lot of money for publishers in New York. In Britain, people are seeing that many self-help books are not very good, but many are published anyway. For every self-help book that is published, many others are not accepted because they are too similar or too specific. Editors are always looking for the next big book. They care more about how well a book can sell than how well it is written. Diane says that if someone has a catchy title, it is a big part of the success.
**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an agreement between the writer and the reader that the truth will be told. But this agreement is often not kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too embarrassing or not important. Sometimes, writers may change the truth to make their story better. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This can happen without the writer being dishonest.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
People who study detective stories say that these stories show the problems of society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. In a detective story, a crime represents a human desire, like greed. Solving the crime helps bring order back to society. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are similar in some ways. The detective understands the criminal, and they have a strange connection. The detective is part of both the law and the crime world. Sometimes, he feels guilty about this.
**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. He said that writing in a fancy place like this is hard. He believes that only scientists can write well about science because they understand it. He also says that writers should not talk down to their readers. They can use simpler words, but they should not make the ideas too simple. If readers feel that the writer is treating them like they are not smart, they will not enjoy the writing.

Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, many workers from the City of London come for lunch. This summer, it is very hot, so the gym uses a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, when it is quiet, the gym feels very cold, like the Arctic. This shows how we often use air-conditioning too much. Air-conditioning is now common in many places, but there are other ways to keep buildings cool. For example, buildings can use sunlight and fresh air. They can also have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
Now, many people are interested in sundials again. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks became better, sundials were mostly used as garden decorations. Now, people are looking at them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I remember seeing china-painting at an art show a long time ago. Older women painted flowers on teacups very carefully. It was amazing to watch them. Their hands were steady, and the paint was perfect. I thought it would be hard to learn china-painting. I wondered if beginners would be good at it. But when I went to a class, it was not scary at all. Everyone was there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport, twelve nights in Venice, in a hotel called Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the holiday, the clerk told them that other people in the group were students from a school. They were learning Italian.
But something went wrong. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Switzerland, not Venice. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard older people speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there was a mistake, maybe a cancellation.
When they arrived, a woman with glasses told them to stay together. They did not expect to stop overnight, but when they got off the coach, it was almost midnight. They were tired and did not ask about their hotel. The next morning, they learned they would stay in the Edelweiss for their holiday. They were worried.
Keith told the receptionist, "We were supposed to be in Venice." The receptionist said he did not know that hotel. Dawne said the name of the travel agency and described the man who booked their trip. 
A woman named Mrs. Franks, who was with the older people, came to help. She said there are many different holidays with the same yellow-and-red labels. She laughed and said they could have ended up anywhere. Keith insisted they were not supposed to be in Switzerland.
Mrs. Franks went away to check. Dawne said she seemed nice, but Keith was thinking about everything that happened. An old man and his wife talked to them. They were happy to be there, but Keith and Dawne felt they were in the wrong place. They wanted a holiday for young people, not a trip with older people. Uncle had said this was a holiday for them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON'**
American business leaders are looking at Ernest Shackleton as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports. 
Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, people are just starting to learn about him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer" whose work was not noticed for most of the 20th century. Now, Americans are very interested in him. Many books and stories about his journey on the Endurance are being made. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is being prepared.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They tell stories about his actions and find lessons in his leadership. They even say they are "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, who used a reindeer sleeping bag and a blubber stove, is now a model for modern management.
Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for many years. His company helps with communication during business changes and crises. He says that even if a company handles a crisis well, it can still hurt itself by communicating poorly. MacGregor believes Shackleton is a good model for management because he was a strong leader and communicator. Shackleton knew what was important, especially when lives were at risk.
One important decision Shackleton made was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed that he cared about his men’s lives. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge.
In 1914, Shackleton's ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice for nine months and was finally crushed. When the ship sank, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." His diaries show that he was always in control. 
MacGregor says Shackleton planned carefully, kept his men informed, and listened to their ideas. He was flexible and ready to change plans if needed. Shackleton believed that an explorer needs to be optimistic, strong, and patient. 
MacGregor explains that in difficult times, it is hard to wait for things to get better, especially in America. If you make a bad investment, it is better to wait than to sell and lose money. Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his gloves and said he would throw them overboard if Hurley did not wear them. 
As Caroline Alexander, who wrote about Shackleton's expedition, says: "People want to hear stories of heroism. Shackleton shows that true heroism is rare today."

'Finding Food in Madagascar'**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is a type of primate, and it has a way of finding food that is similar to a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes in the wood and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to make holes and its long finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied how aye-ayes find insects. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might be.
Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with holes. Some holes had food inside, and some were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food. They did not need to see the holes to find the mealworms. They might have found the food by smell or sound, but tests showed they did not use these senses either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked or when the mealworms were quiet.
So, how did the aye-ayes find the food? Dr. Erickson found that they could feel the empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. It seems to be using a method called echo-location, which means it listens for sounds that bounce back to it. This helps the aye-aye know where the hollow spaces are.
Some people think that the aye-aye acts like a woodpecker in Madagascar, but there are also birds that look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is not just like a woodpecker; it also has some behaviors like a squirrel. Its teeth keep growing, just like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild opening nuts and eating the inside with its long finger.

Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like? We often have only small pieces of information from old diaries or family stories. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We want to write things down, but we often forget. We might leave videos instead of photos, but videos are not the same as real life.
Hannah Renier has a solution. She writes life stories for other people. She makes a book with at least 20,000 words and pictures if needed. She focuses on ordinary people, not famous ones. Hannah got this idea when she talked to her family and saw how much of the past was being lost.
"When I started, I didn’t take it very seriously," she says. "But then I met people who have interesting stories. They want to share their stories for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it."
People feel safe to share their stories with Hannah. A 62-year-old man said, "I was honest. I talked about my divorce and the pain I felt." He wrote his story for his family but hasn’t let his children read it yet. He thinks some details might hurt them.
Hannah has noticed that many people repeat the same mistakes in their lives. "Many people are affected by their parents," she says. "What parents say to their children can stay with them for a long time. Some people marry people their parents like, while others choose the opposite to rebel."
Many people still feel sad about things that happened when they were young. They try to impress parents who are hard to please. Sometimes, they want to say, "I can’t stand my mother."
Hannah listens to people without judging them. "I’m not here to be nosy," she says. People sometimes share things and then worry if they should have said them. Hannah tells them they can change things later if they want.
Hannah’s books are not for everyone to read. They are personal stories. She believes we are losing touch with our past. Writing these stories helps people connect with their family history. 
Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these talks to write the life story, organizing it in a clear way. The final book looks nice and costs about £3,000, with extra copies costing £25 each. She gets about 10 requests each week, but the price stops many people from buying.
"I thought more people would want this," she says. "But the people I work with are often wealthy and like to read certain magazines."

**Text:**
**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred pieces. Remember, none of these sculptures are real. They are all copies made from the originals, mostly made in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The Museum has a special gallery with good natural light. The plaster copies are useful because you can see many sculptures that were once together but are now in different museums. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has community darkrooms and a gallery with different photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skills. Our popular courses include a Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with special photographers. Members can use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (ages 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members scheme, led by our photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and have many photography materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). There are nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original cabinets from the early 1700s. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and helped to grow the collection. The collection is organized by geological age, showing how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery has beautiful minerals and gems. There are labels to explain what they are and how they are used today.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection. These were taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The university has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs all over Great Britain. The photographs show the landscape and how it has changed from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photographs, but you can buy copies. These are made to order and usually take about a month.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is one of the oldest and most interesting tourist attractions in the area. You can have fun making wall hangings by rubbing over one of more than a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre makes resin copies to protect the originals and make brass rubbing easy for everyone. The brass plates were used as memorials and came from Germany to medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed in revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain. You can see the largest variety at the Cambridge Centre.

From Here to Being a Parent**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have enjoyed 35 years with small children. I loved feeding my baby this morning. For me, being a father is about love. I am very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This brings us close, especially now that they are older and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have done it when I was angry, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the best father, but I always tried to be there for them. I wait for them to call me. If I chase them to ask why they have not called, it makes them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I will not do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, about 25 years old. I found the responsibilities hard at first, but they also kept me young. As they became teenagers, they showed me new things like music and fashion. This helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. But now, I can take them on holidays to nice places, and they enjoy being with my friends at parties and events.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just before I started my job in politics. I promised my wife that we would spend time with our children, but my job takes a lot of time. I only go to meetings on weekends if my kids can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am always away. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their kids to work. Maybe we all want to include our children in our lives more.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I had to think a lot about being a father. I tried hard to stay close to my children. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate said we were too relaxed as parents. I wish I had set more rules. I still worry about my older daughters just like I do about my youngest. In that way, you never stop being a parent.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for kids when I turned 30. I met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new things?" Having my daughter, Betty, made me think about who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but when I see her smile, all my irritation goes away. A baby's smile is very powerful.

**THEATRE**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play by Marlowe is about a strong warrior. It can feel very long, but it is exciting. The director, Terry Hands, has cut some parts of the text to make it faster and more lively. Antony Sher plays the main character and does amazing things, like jumping from the balcony and sliding down a rope. He keeps the audience's attention with his powerful performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. In the first part, two married couples talk on a sunny lawn, creating a tense feeling. In the second part, the story changes and shows the serious effects of illness. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died too young at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one talks about the problems in the fishing industry. It has strong characters, deep emotions, and some funny moments. Sometimes the story feels a bit slow, but it ends with a strong finish.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about a "perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar, but it has interesting twists.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's funny play about tricksters from the 17th century. The show was first seen in Stratford and is now at the Barbican. Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce give great performances as the three con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James directs this comedy by Harley Granville Barker about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian times. It is now in London after being successful at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn tells a sweet version of Beauty and the Beast set in a London suburb. It has beautiful music by John Pattison and celebrates romantic love. This show is sure to be a hit.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's funny play is not very good, but the actors, Ron Cook and Anton Lesser, give great performances. They make the show better, even if the design is not good.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important play by Granville Barker, now touring. It tells the story of a lawyer who leaves a bad financial legacy to his son. It is a wonderful play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek**  
Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game. They are watching a strange bookshop when Emma sees her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to make her not trust her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is locked in a dark cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and that adults are not always safe. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together. They find out that their family members were involved in a train accident in 1915, where eight people died. The story uses different points of view and documents like maps and personal stories to help the reader understand what happened. It is a clever and complex novel that needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer**  
Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer does not fit in with her family. She loves her father's racing pigeons. When her father goes away for work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story teaches that "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
Robert Westall  
In this story, a woman named Rose wants to escape her busy life. She rents a cottage with her two children. A fierce cat and strange things in the cottage help explain why the last owner, Yaxley, disappeared. But the locals do not like them, and their lives are in danger. In the end, the violence stops, but Rose is worried about her son.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
Harry Mazer  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy. He admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a rich family. When Lisa's life becomes difficult, Sam helps her find balance. The story is a bit slow in parts, but it has gentle humor and shows how the two teenagers grow closer. It can be interesting for both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
Barry Faville  
Barry Faville writes with humor and describes New Zealand well. Robbie takes a job gardening for an old man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is scared. When she discovers what is in his aquarium and what he plans to do, the story becomes thrilling but still shows good character development.
**Dodger**  
Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has problems with his family and school. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. Mick learns to deal with his problems through a school play and a caring teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a very emotional read, especially at the end.

**Flying Without Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the students that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135, which is based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights on the walls. Most of the seats were taken out, except for a few at the back where the 13 students from Europe and America sat. They were excited but also nervous.
For 12 months, these students had worked hard to be part of this flight. The European Space Agency gave them a challenge to create interesting experiments to do in weightlessness. The students with the best ideas got to go on this special flight, which felt like a big roller-coaster ride. 
For the next two hours, the plane would go up and down like a bird. The pilot would turn off the engines at 3,000 meters, and the plane would go higher for a moment before falling back down. During this time, everything inside the plane would be weightless. The students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to the Earth.
The plane took off smoothly, but soon the pilot made the plane climb steeply. The engines roared, and the students felt heavy. Then, the engines stopped, and they felt weightless. For 20 seconds, they floated in the air. It was like jumping on a trampoline. They could not tell which way was up or down. 
After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane up again. Gravity came back, and some students landed hard. They had 30 curves to go through, which gave them 10 minutes of weightlessness for their experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats land on their feet. They released a device to help with this, but another student accidentally landed on it during a curve.
A German team studied how metal joins are affected by weightlessness, which could help build future space stations. Another group from Utah State University worked on making solar sails from thin films. They hoped to use these sails in satellites to catch sunlight like a boat catches wind.
After two hours of flying, the students felt excited, not sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.
I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is winter in New Zealand. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you plant trees on it, you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is good for planting trees.
I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so the idea of planting trees sounded nice, and I was excited. My family also became excited as we went along. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres together.
In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot. It was strange to think of that time as happy because it rained almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been so wet or cold for so long. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready to plant again. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but the rain was falling, and my clothes were still wet from the day before. My hands were slippery with the laces of my boots.
In that first year, I had a helper who was good at planting trees, which was helpful because I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck and fill it with trees. When the bag is full, it is heavy, but when it gets lighter, it is easier to work. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you line up three poles to help you. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down the line, then turn around and come back.
I enjoy hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use the least number of movements to dig a hole. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You learn to take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in the ground, stamp it down, and move on. 
It is also interesting for the mind. I started to think about many things, like nature and our place in it. These thoughts became important in my life. I have been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow. It feels good to see the trees I planted. I worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. But everything worked out well, and the trees are now 20 years old and healthy.
I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months. I was alone and wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*. There is a small cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. I still feel a strong connection to that place. It is where I feel closest to the bond between people and the earth.

'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**
"What now?" I thought, as one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset. We take care of orphaned animals. But the noise from the box was strange, so I looked inside. I saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. They had soft coats and milky eyes looking up at me from their black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badger cubs are born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. 
These three cubs were found by builders. While they were working, they accidentally dug into the badger's home. The mother was found dead, and her babies were still trying to drink from her. I could see the cubs were healthy but cold and crying. After cleaning them, I took them to the kitchen to keep them warm. There were two girls, Primrose and Bluebell, and one boy, Willow. At first, I used a syringe to feed them. I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to make them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around.
Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was not as active, but he was still eating. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When feeding animals with a bottle, it is important not to let them drink too fast. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat.
I was sad about Willow, but I continued to care for the other cubs. Six days later, a local farmer came to see me. He found another male cub, alone and cold. He knew the mother would not come back. This new cub, Willow II, joined us. He was younger than the girls. I had a hard time feeding him. I had to move the bottle around and squeeze it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally drink.
By the end of April, the girls were eating rice and other food. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle, but he made a mess when eating. I gave him a sausage, and he slowly learned to eat it. After a week, he was ready for more food. At five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, and eggs for dinner. Badgers usually eat a lot of earthworms, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were doing well, especially since it was a hot summer and finding food was hard.
By August, the badgers started to be active at night. We took walks in the orchard, and they would chase each other and play. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek sometimes got caught and had funny reactions. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food because their homes were disturbed. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and hurt the cubs, so we made the gate hard to open.
The local newspaper took pictures of me walking the badgers. Many people wanted to help build a home for the badgers on our farm. With help, we designed a new home for them. Our son Daniel made the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels and a special gate. It had three rooms, one bigger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside. As we built it, the badgers explored the new home. They became excited and forgot about their walks.
The building cost more than we thought, but a local bus company helped pay for it, and other businesses gave materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them alone. Half an hour later, I checked on them and saw three badgers sleeping in their rooms.
Now, I don’t walk with them as often because they wake up late. We see Primrose sometimes because she has joined another sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy here.

In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, he also did important work to understand how compasses work. He used his sea trips on a warship called Paramore to study the 'variations of the compass'. These variations are now called 'declination', which is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this information to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.
Halley planned to travel to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip ended early because of problems with the crew, but he tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a chart showing the compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. His work helped sailors for many years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made the charts less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing the route of the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. He says, "Halley led a remarkable life. He was a respected scientist and led many expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics."
Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica. Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's journey will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. Dr. Clark will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.
Dr. Clark explains, "It is common to measure the size of the magnetic field, but not the direction. You need to know true north to measure the direction." On this trip, they will use satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the measurements. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his work will help fill in any gaps in the data.
Halley's journey was very important. It was the first scientific expedition at sea, and Halley was the first civilian to be a naval captain for this kind of work. Dr. Clark has experience for this journey. He spent two years in Antarctica and has sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews. 
When asked if he is obsessed like Halley, Dr. Clark said, "I am ready to give up my life for eight months to do this. Some people might think I'm obsessed, but I want to have a good reason to sail across the Atlantic again. Halley and his life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**PEACOCKS IN WHIPSNADE PARK**
Every summer, peacocks walk freely in Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire. They show their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior makes people wonder why peacocks have such big and colorful tails. Charles Darwin, a famous scientist, thought about this question for a long time. He believed that animals change over time through a process called evolution. In nature, the strongest and best animals usually survive and have babies. 
However, Darwin thought that peacocks' tails were not useful for survival. He suggested another idea called "sexual selection." This means that female peacocks (called peahens) choose males based on their beauty. Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if peahens liked the most beautiful peacocks, it was because those peacocks had some special quality that helped them survive.
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still studying this question. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people. Marion Petrie and her team want to find out two things: Do peahens really choose the peacocks with the most beautiful tails? And do these peacocks have other good qualities, or is it just about looks?
The scientists watch the peacocks and take pictures. They see that peahens do prefer the peacocks with the most eye spots on their tails. The peacocks with the most eye spots attract more mates. But the scientists still need to find out if these peacocks are better in other ways.
William Hamilton, another scientist, thinks that beautiful male birds are often healthier and have fewer parasites. This means their beautiful feathers show that they are healthy. However, the team has not yet been able to check the health of the peacocks at Whipsnade.
This year, Dr. Petrie is studying the babies of attractive peacocks and those of less attractive ones. She wants to see if the babies of the attractive peacocks grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would mean that the peahens' choice is smart, just like Wallace said.
There is also an interesting idea from a scientist named R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female peahen chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their babies will have long tails too. Over time, this could lead to peacocks having very long tails. This idea also supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty for its own sake.
**Questions:**
1. Where do the peacocks live?
2. What do peacocks show to attract peahens?
3. What is the name of the scientist who thought about evolution?
4. What do scientists want to find out about peahens' choices?
5. What do the scientists think about the health of beautiful male birds?

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He made this idea real with his own boat, called 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. 
In contrast, my boat is quiet and sits in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic for owning it. Maybe I am, but I don’t think so. My boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but modern technology has helped a lot. 
However, new technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real life at sea. Many sailors want to feel the sea and the wind, not just use machines. I don’t think sailors should go back to having a hard life, but I like my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if everything is done by machines? Sometimes, dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor. 
A boat should feel like a boat, not a big house on the water. When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV show, the last owner said it had comfort but no luxury. He was right. Hirta had heavy sails and no running water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics, but she was the easiest boat I ever sailed. 
On land, classic boats need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing Hirta. I looked for a younger boat but found nothing good, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. 'The Westerman' has never let me down. 
The designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, are good with computer design, but Irens first drew this boat on a paper napkin. Later, he used a computer to make the design better. We worked together to improve the boat. The final design was perfect. 
Now, 'The Westerman' has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and feels peaceful inside. This is because she was designed only as a sailing boat, not as a house. 
Made from special wood, she does not take in water. So, she has the good points of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

'RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE'**
Health farms and country hotels with spa services are very popular now. Five journalists visited some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started to join classes like yoga and body conditioning. The teachers were very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They have many treatments, like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment lasts an hour and makes you feel great. The staff were very friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to make some changes this year, including a swimming pool. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a walk in the garden. I felt happy and full of energy when I left. I want to visit again. This is a great place for busy women. 
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. When I arrived, I saw a big staircase and a nice library. Everyone gets a health check when they arrive. They check your weight and blood pressure. I felt a bit strange being called a patient because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem, and I worked on it in group classes and private sessions. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit. If you are not on a diet, you can eat tasty food in the dining hall. You can also have massages or water therapy every other day. 
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys Manor is not a health farm, but it is a nice old manor with a cozy lounge. If you want to lose weight, you might not enjoy the rich food. The chef makes delicious meals. The hotel has a gym and a pool to help you stay fit. There is also a spa, sauna, and treatment rooms. I got help for an old shoulder injury from a physiotherapist. Careys is comfortable and relaxing, and there is beautiful countryside to explore.
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a beautiful country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, and horse riding. There are lovely walks and gardens around the estate. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. I enjoyed my meal, especially the sticky-toffee pudding. The next morning, I spent time in the gym before my next meal. I had a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options if you want to use them.
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is very delicious but has a lot of calories. The second best thing is the aromatherapy massage. I felt so relaxed during the massage that I fell asleep. The place is modern and well-organized, with many therapists and beauty rooms. There are many treatments available, like manicures and facials. The guests are a mix of people, including families and friends. I would love to visit Springs Hydro every month.

This simplified text keeps the main ideas and information while using easier language for A2 learners.

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the last seven million years, humans and chimpanzees have changed very little. We are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very new. Our ability to make art and do other things that are special to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 
Studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are also found in animals. For example, chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. This means that there are not many clear differences between humans and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from special genes, it is strange that our ancestors did not make art for almost seven million years. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we do not have proof of this because these materials do not last. The first clear evidence of human art is from the Cro-Magnons, about 35,000 years ago. They made cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
Some people say that human art is different from animal art in three ways: human art is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive. 
First, Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. Some human art does communicate ideas, but this is not the same as passing on genes. For example, birds sing to defend their territory or attract a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. 
Second, human art is thought to be made for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during the breeding season, so they may not sing just for beauty. 
Third, human art is learned. Different human groups have their own art styles. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' song, even if they have never heard it before.
Human art changes quickly. For example, people can tell when a painting was made just by looking at it. In 1957, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy had an art show in London. Congo made many paintings and seemed to enjoy it. Their paintings were sold, which is something many human artists cannot do.
These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal behavior is not so clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for a specific purpose; they were made for the enjoyment of the painter. Some might say that human art is different because it is meant to communicate, while the chimpanzees did not care about sharing their art. However, some famous human art was also made just for the artist's own pleasure.

A Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unknown places on Earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. Children's stories used to have brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far away on their journeys. Today, we do not see such people in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing trip while at home with his family. The team he led had four British people (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. Later, they found out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for everyone.
This group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 happy years. He started the trip for fun and to find out more about himself. "I thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I wanted to see who I really was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I would not come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what would happen. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very good to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will wonder why he said the desert was "good." The team faced many problems: sickness, extreme heat and cold, thirst, and losing some of their water. "But," Blackmore said, "when we were very tired and the camels had not had water for seven days, we found some. We did not have the famous sandstorms of the Taklamakan. And we did not feel the freezing cold that could have stopped us. But we were always fighting against problems. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high sand dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavy camels, which sometimes fell over."
"What pushed me on was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No planes flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I could handle the trip mentally, but I was scared about my physical strength. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was hard at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have gone through so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but strong despite being tired. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of the book, Blackmore described lying in the desert, looking at the full moon, and thinking of his family. How did he feel about what they went through? "Inside me, I am trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we did it together. I feel prouder of that trip than anything else I have done. But when I think of my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We felt good because we had a purpose. Now, it is hard for me to be part of the same routine of modern life."

Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful tools that make life easier. But sometimes, technology can cause problems. For example, Susan had a bad experience with her broken computer. She had to pay a lot of money to fix it, and this made her think that gadgets are not always worth it.
Susan started to stop using some of her household gadgets. She wondered if technology really gives us more time. Does it just make us buy more gadgets? When her broken machine made strange noises, she left it outside. Now, she enjoys taking her time to sew by hand. She feels free and not tied to a noisy machine. 
There are some gadgets she still likes, like her washing machine. But she also found joy in not watching too much television. She returned her color TV and now uses a small black-and-white one. This helps her spend more time walking her dog, reading, and talking with family. 
Susan used to think she needed her sewing machine, but now she sews by hand. She enjoys it and can listen to the radio or talk to friends while she works. Sewing by hand is relaxing, and she feels happy to see her work improve. 
Now, she takes her time with chores like washing dishes and thinks about what gadgets she really needs. She wonders if they could live without things like the freezer or microwave. Susan feels that life is better when she does things slowly and enjoys them. 
**Questions:**
1. Why did Susan decide to unplug her gadgets?
2. What problem did Susan have with her computer?
3. What does Susan enjoy doing instead of using a sewing machine?
4. How does Susan feel when she sews by hand?
5. What does Susan think about the gadgets in her house?

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy, and his workshop is full of furniture pieces and wood in many colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a good reputation. He always has many orders, even though he does not advertise himself. People say that if you want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, you should go to Hurst.
It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is harder to find one who makes high-quality furniture. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of some modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced furniture and wants to make perfect pieces. This desire for perfection helps him succeed.
Hurst is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work comes from private clients. Some clients come back to him many times. He enjoys doing work for them, but he finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want.
Hurst is also kind and praises others when they deserve it. He says, "There are people far better than me." He does not like craftsmen who take a long time to make one piece of furniture or students who try to make their work look fashionable. He believes furniture should be useful, not just a statement.
Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. Sleep is very important, but scientists do not fully agree on why we need it. There are three main ideas about sleep.
The first idea says that sleep is good for our bodies. When we sleep, our bodies work to fix any damage from the day and help us feel better.
The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us understand and remember things we learned during the day. Without sleep, it is hard to learn new things.
The third idea is about energy. This idea says we need sleep to recharge our energy. When we sleep, we get ready for the next day.
These three ideas help us understand why sleep is important.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, someone might love entering contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the newspaper about many topics. Being eccentric shows our individuality.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. It is like having two trains on the same track, pushing against each other. One train is called individualism (being yourself) and the other is conformity (fitting in). Most of the time, we want to fit in more than we want to stand out. We want to be accepted and liked by others.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs and hold meetings to talk about their interests. They want to share what others might think is strange. Being in a group, even a small one, can make us feel better.
We all feel this push and pull between being ourselves and fitting in. Even when we follow the crowd, we might not like it if someone points it out. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is different. 
Anyone can choose to be more individual. Many people succeed in their jobs by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing and go for it, you will surprise many people." But being different does not always mean being eccentric. 
For example, if a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, that is not eccentricity. But if they keep doing it until it feels normal for them, then they might be eccentric. The key to eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are.
True eccentrics do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, without worrying about what others think.

Natural Books**
We asked four naturalists to tell us about the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy for me to choose the author. I am an environmental journalist, and I have met many important people in this field. One of the most important is Barbara Ward. She is a small, frail woman, but she has done a lot for environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences into her own ideas about the environment. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand everything better. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think Barbara's most important book is "The Home of Man." It talks about the fast growth of cities and important themes she cared about. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the guano in the sun. This book explains the amazing world of animal communication with words and pictures. If you read "Signals for Survival" and then watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaos turns into a smart social structure. You can see which birds are partners and where their boundaries are. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to explain his work to everyone. He worked with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion to create this book. Ennion's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and how another is calm. This is the art of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book helped me find a wonderful husband and a great career in conservation. It also made me love the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read this book. I had been there for two years and was feeling sad because of many problems. But when I opened "My Family and Other Animals," I felt happy again. The book shows animals and people together, creating a beautiful world worth saving. Some people say humans are bad because of what we have done to nature. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family. This is an idea we all need to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library after it was published in 1966. I loved it right away, especially the 48 colorful bird pictures by Eric Ennion. These pictures caught my attention. I already had other bird books and spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" had even more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters about bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and a chapter about birds in music, literature, and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature more. It showed me that my feelings and creativity about nature are just as important as scientific facts. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in the newspaper. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or word of mouth. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers feel bad when there are no reviews. But publishers think that even bad reviews can help sell books because people want to read the book themselves. Publishers like reviews that match their own thoughts about a book.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both want good book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed well. Book reviews today are better than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help readers find out about books. A good review from a trusted person can help sell more books.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we need reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they show that the review is honest. Publishers say they want big reviews, but the real effect of reviews on sales is hard to understand. Good reviews can help a book and an author become popular, but they need help from other things like recommendations and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I am not sure about the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain. In the United States, a review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops do not always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews can still sell very well. It is hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction books allow reviewers to talk more about the subject than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I published a biography that got great reviews, but it did not sell well. People thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people listened to them. Now, sometimes an unexpected reviewer or a clever review can make people want to buy the book.

WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith continues this craft in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs for his customers. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women who want to buy gifts for their husbands. They look for something special that shows the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel, which is a common design. Instead, it was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. He realized he could make many different designs. Graham decided to start a weathervane business. Before this, he worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed their roles. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of their children and grow the business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic. I love designing."
Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays attention to detail and always asks the customer to approve the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs because people like them. Graham says, "People enjoy handmade items. They want something different."
Graham does not want to grow his business too much because he wants to keep it a local craft. He feels he has found his place in the market. People appreciate the unique designs, and he enjoys seeing a simple shape become something beautiful. For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing changes in the wind. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add special touches to their homes. This has helped crafts like his.
Graham is now very busy, sending weathervanes to customers all over the world. He has many buyers from America and Denmark. He explains that the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

'The Horse Whisperer'**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was a very popular book. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. He talks about his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was not doing well. A film he was working on, called *Life and Limb*, did not happen. He was worried because he had not earned money for two years, and he needed to pay his bank. A smart person would have found a job, but instead, Evans made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.
He had an idea for the story from a farrier he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became very wild. The owners were sad until they heard about a gypsy who could talk to the horse and change its behavior quickly. These people are called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans.
He started to learn more about horses and the people who work with them. He drove around the US, visiting ranches. He felt alone and worried about his life and money. He had tried for ten years to be a filmmaker, but now he was in debt and worried about his family.
By the end of August, he returned home and had written half of the book. He was still worried about money and showed his work to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Evans could get $30,000 for the book. Evans needed more money to pay his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and needed more time to finish it.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the book to seven publishers in the UK. Soon, his agent called to say that they had turned down an offer of $75,000. Evans was surprised. His agent felt something good was going to happen.
A week later, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. This was a record for a first novel. Evans and his team were shocked. They had not sent the book to New York, but it got there anyway. Many film studios wanted to make a movie from the book. 
One night, four famous filmmakers called Evans to ask for the rights to the book. He decided not to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. He felt it was a great story and did not want to spoil it. He wanted to write another novel instead.

Bobby Fischer is trying to come back to chess. He is not as young as he used to be. Chess is now a game for younger players. After being away from chess for 20 years, Bobby Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky, his old rival. Bobby won the first game, but he is now 49 years old and not in good shape. Boris Spassky is also older. 
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. It is now more professional. Players want to win more than anything else. In chess, a player needs to be calm and strong, not just smart. The game is very intense. Players have a time limit to make their moves, and if they do not finish in time, they lose. Games can be long, and players often do not take breaks. 
Today, many of the best players are under 30 years old. Most of the top ten players in the world are young. Chess is also played differently now. Players prepare a lot before matches. They use computers to study many chess games. In some recent matches, players had teams of helpers to find weaknesses in their opponent's games. 
A chess game can last up to eight hours. Players must stay focused because losing concentration can lead to losing the game. The chess clock makes the game even more stressful. At the end of the game, players often have very little time to make their moves. They must think and move quickly. 
Winning a game feels great, but one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess tournaments can last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. The world championship matches are even harder. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov had to stop after many months because both players were too tired. 
Bobby Fischer once said, "All I want to do is play chess." He left the chess world in 1972, which was surprising. If he is back for the money, he will earn a lot. But if he wants to prove he is still the best, it could be very hard for him. 
**Questions:**
1. How old is Bobby Fischer now?
2. Who is Bobby Fischer playing against?
3. What do players use to prepare for chess matches today?
4. How long can a chess game last?
5. What did Bobby Fischer say about playing chess?

Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is a man in his early 30s. He has written three plays that many people like. Now, he is changing his first play, Peaches, into a movie script. He says, "It is low budget, but I don’t know how low. It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before he wrote Peaches, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed. It is set in a car. I probably wouldn’t do that now because I know it is hard to do." He left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People’s Theatre. He realized he wanted to write for actors. He wanted people to hear his writing. He says, "Suddenly, I was with people like me. It was the first time I enjoyed school."
**B** Simon Pegg is 28 years old and has worked hard in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and just finished a tough tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon remembers, "At university, it was very theoretical. I realized I didn’t want to be a regular actor. I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn’t. If you have courage and good material, it is great to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his best work has been with Steve Coogan. Simon says, "He saw my show, and I was a big fan of his."
**C** Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became known when he danced in the show The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. People liked his performance, and now he can choose what he wants to do. He says, "It is great to be in this position." Ciaran started acting in school and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He laughs and says, "I used acting to avoid homework. But then I decided I wanted to do it seriously because I loved it." Now, he waits for good things to happen, but he thinks about fame. He says, "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but you realize it is not why you act. It is about getting respect for good work."
**D** Neil Taylor is 25 years old and the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They have just signed a deal to make three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very popular when their single, Chimera, comes out. Neil says, "The record company thinks good sales are very different from what I think.
