If two people buy it, I will be happy." Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for eight years. He says, "I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino Records. It was a good time for me."
**E** Stephen Richards is 27 years old. He is a poet and author who has won many awards. He is well known in the poetry world and has been giving readings for six years. His first novel, Hidden, will be published in March. He says, "It is a story about obsessive love. I could not write it as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but later did not like school. He decided not to go to university but later got bored with a job at a theatre. He published his first book, a children's book, in 1992. He says, "My parents thought I would be a reader, not a writer." Now, he is brave to write novels. He explains, "Poetry has rules, but a novel can be any length. I want to make sure my writing is good."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student. She thinks she looks good in jeans, but she does not wear them often. She is looking for the right man but worries that her knees are not nice enough. Isabel has hope, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a fun and lively way, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."
B. This story is about a local radio station in America. It is told from the view of a smart child named Francis. Francis works for WLT Radio, which was started by two men to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays music and has different people talking. The author uses humor to show life in a small town and takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old cars and radios.
C. In this story, a second husband talks to his wife's first husband. Richard, a professor, falls in love with a Russian poet. The poet writes bad poetry, which makes Richard feel guilty. She also wants help for her brother, who is in prison. The author tells this story in a funny and clever way, making it enjoyable to read.
D. In London during the 1960s, two sets of best friends meet. One of them, James, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard. This is important because a woman they both loved was killed years ago. The story has murder, love, and jealousy. The writing is good, and you can really get to know the characters.
E. This story is by a great American writer. It is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming a strange bachelor. The story shows Ian's loving relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that mixes sadness and laughter.

Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about international volunteer work.
A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money to the local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is especially true for young people who take a gap year. They often do not have special skills or experience. Many studies ask if young people volunteer to help others or if they want to improve their own careers. However, these projects can help people learn to care for those who have less.
B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can also help solve problems and create connections between people from different countries. In this way, everyone can benefit, and it can help the world. But if only rich people can volunteer, it may help them more than the communities that need help. Those who volunteer may gain experience and connections, but it does not help those who cannot volunteer.
C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to help themselves while pretending to help others. It can also be a way to give real help to communities. At its best, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the communities. It can also make people more aware of problems like poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits with the idea of helping others. This idea can seem good, especially when people do not trust big governments or businesses. However, it can also ignore the need for real change in poor communities. Some people think that volunteering is just simple charity. But when volunteer tourism is sold as a way to help develop communities, it can show a misunderstanding of real development needs. The way we think about volunteer tourism can ignore the serious problems of inequality and poverty in the world.

Sound the Alarm**
Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need an alarm to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?
A group of us tested five clock radios. We included Tom Granger, an inventor, and Paul Bridges, a broadcaster. One clock radio has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. But who really needs that? This clock radio costs about the same as another model, but it has a cassette player. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to music instead of news. We all liked the radio quality, but it was very big, like a rugby ball. Paul said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also likes to book a wake-up call just in case the alarm does not work.
This clock radio was voted the best. Paul said he loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 4:00 PM. I liked the digital display with nice grey numbers on a green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can press it easily when you are still half asleep. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, and I accidentally pressed them too much. The clock has a backup battery, so it still works if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. But setting it up was hard, even though it made us feel cool when we finally did it.
Tom thought this model, which has a lamp, looked cheap. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work. The light was hard to adjust, and you could not read by it. Paul thought the lamp was funny but agreed that tuning the radio was difficult. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm, and I wanted to throw it across the room. Still, this model is popular with young people because it looks bright and fun. Tom liked it because it stands out. It was the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. But the alarm could go off 10 minutes early or late, which Paul thought was silly. He said this model was hard to use and not very good.
The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to set up. With modern buttons, you are not sure if you pressed them right. Tom agreed that radio quality has improved with new technology. I thought the tuning was not very good, but the radio worked well. The buzzer on this model got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. When a hedgehog is in danger, it can roll into a tight ball. This way, its spines point outwards to protect it. The number of spines helps with this defense. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They may try to run away from danger instead of rolling up.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They often sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all of them do. Some hedgehogs stay awake all year if the conditions are good.

Great Sportswomen**
It is hard to be good at any sport, even for men, but women have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they must make sacrifices. Despite this, they are overcoming challenges and breaking records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love to ski and feel great when I jump and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel good or the weather is bad, but I keep going. I train for ten months each year, so I miss a lot of time with friends. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete together."
B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won! I was surprised because I had never cycled before. Now, I earn good money as a professional cyclist. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do some stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools have rowing teams. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches often change, so it can be difficult. But I enjoy it and like being fit, and I have a good social life."
D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I didn’t know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very painful. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! Some people think women are more likely to fail, so they are less likely to sponsor us."
E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they ignore me. Being a woman in racing can be hard. Men often want to beat me, and I have had many accidents. It is tough to earn money, and what I make goes back into racing. More women are racing now, which is great!"
F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need to sleep more on other mornings. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Sometimes I feel tired at work! Racing is hard, but I feel happy when I stay fit. Men and women usually compete together, but the media often focuses more on men. The prize money for women is not as good, but we are working to change that."

One day, Richard Cork, who was 78 years old, remembers meeting the famous artist Picasso. Even from far away, he could see Picasso eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes. Richard was 18 years old and was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. He had run out of money and found a job painting boats. But he spent a lot of time drawing and had a sketchbook with him when he saw Picasso.
Picasso usually stayed at home, so Richard was surprised to see him at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. Richard was nervous but asked Picasso for his signature. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and wrote his name on Richard's paper. Then, he drew some lines on the page. These lines might have looked like a cloud, the sea, or the shape of the harbour.
Richard thanked Picasso and started a conversation. Picasso did not speak much English, and an American woman at the table helped translate. She called Picasso "the Maestro," which made it hard for Richard to talk. But he told Picasso that he loved art and admired his work.
After a while, Richard went back to his boat and showed his friend the signature. His friend asked, "Is that all?" and told Richard to go back and talk to Picasso again. So, Richard took his sketchbook and returned to Picasso's table. He did not ask if he could draw Picasso's portrait because he was afraid Picasso would say no. Instead, he just started to draw.
When Picasso saw Richard drawing, he made funny faces to distract him. He rolled his eyes and stuck out his tongue, acting like a clown. Richard wanted to stop, but he felt challenged to keep drawing. Finally, Picasso sat still for a few minutes, allowing Richard to study him. Richard noticed that Picasso looked strong and young for his age.
When the American woman said Picasso wanted to see Richard's drawing, Richard felt shy and thought it was not good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when Richard showed it to him, Picasso nodded in approval. Then, to Richard's surprise, Picasso wanted to draw too. Richard quickly gave him a crayon, and Picasso made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a face that looked very different from Richard's drawing.
Richard thanked Picasso and asked him to sign the new drawing. The American woman said that Picasso said he already gave Richard his signature. Richard felt lucky to meet Picasso and to have his attention. It meant a lot to him. 
**Questions:**
1. How old was Richard Cork when he met Picasso?
2. Where did Richard see Picasso?
3. What did Richard ask Picasso for?
4. Who helped Richard talk to Picasso?
5. What did Picasso do when Richard started to draw him?

Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.
A. **Fresh and Nice**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that makes the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The color green is often used because it makes people think of fresh food. But most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen food and cleaning products, is not fresh.
B. **Where Things Are**  
The place where products are in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where people like to shop. They put popular products in these places. Items at eye level are more likely to be bought. Special offers in big bins can also attract shoppers. Sometimes, they put items that go well together near each other, like ice cream and dessert toppings.
C. **Moving Basic Items**  
Supermarkets often place basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting products. Stores may also put popular items far away, hoping that customers will look for them and see other products on the way.
D. **Less is More**  
Some stores, like Next, show their clothes in a way that makes them look special. They do not put many items on the shelves, which makes shoppers think the clothes are exclusive. This good design helps the store sell more.
E. **Total Price Matters**  
Shoppers often care more about the total price of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. They sometimes sell basic items at a loss to bring people in, which is called "loss leaders." They can get lower prices by buying in large amounts.
F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers usually buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, a blouse priced at £14.99 seems cheaper than one at £15. This pricing trick can also help reduce theft.
G. **Lighting**  
Stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.
H. **Store Layout**  
Many stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the way through the store, and another shows sales areas. This helps to lead customers to different sections. Some stores use nice carpets in sales areas to make them more inviting.
I. **Promotions**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see big pictures of delicious food. In some places, shopping carts have screens that show ads for products while you shop. These ads are meant to catch the attention of shoppers and can increase sales a lot.

Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also made new climbing paths in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, like *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. 
Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his boat, Sunhaili. He also set a record for sailing from New York to the Lizard in just 10 days. Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote a book about their trip called *Sea, Ice and Rock*.
In 1979, Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure*. He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to go sailing. Chris could teach Robin some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris about sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin paddled to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was hard, but Chris was impressed with how steady Robin was.
When they reached a big drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to climb down. Robin wanted to use his arms like he did on his boat, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Chris was not happy about it, but Robin got down safely.
During this trip, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they go on a big trip to Greenland together. Chris thought Robin was a great leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions. Most of the time, people did not give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decisions.
Chris found sailing boring. He liked the exciting moments, but he did not like being in the middle of the sea for many days. Chris preferred land, while Robin loved sailing and fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because Robin did not need his help. The boat was also very small for six people.
When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing expedition. He felt nervous about keeping Robin safe. Climbing the Cathedral, the highest mountain in Greenland, was harder than Chris thought. Robin was not a natural climber, but he tried very hard. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes. Robin trusted Chris completely and followed him. When it became too hard, they decided to turn back. Robin was also worried about their boat and if it would be okay.
The only time they had a problem was on the way home. They took turns watching the boat. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am, but Robin did not wake him. Robin thought he could do it alone. Chris felt that Robin did not trust him, and he told Robin how he felt. Robin quickly reassured Chris that he was wrong to think that. 
They enjoyed their trip to Skye, but they really got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. Chris discovered that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A Simple History of the Apple**
Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the different kinds of apples we have.
**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, people left apple parts near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored apple halves for winter. These apples were small and wild, called crab apples. They were very different from the apples we eat today.
**Norman Apples (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple types, but many did not grow well in Britain. British monks started to create new apple types, and many of today’s apples come from these.
**Popular Apples in the Middle Ages (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a common dessert apple. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But many problems, like droughts and the Black Death, made it hard to grow apples. So, more apples were brought in from other places. In the sixteenth century, King Henry VIII sent a man to France to learn about growing apples. He brought back many new types, including the famous Pippins.
**Apples and Settlers (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A famous apple planter in North America was Johnny Appleseed. He planted many apple trees and was known for his kindness to animals.
**Delicious Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. When a judge tasted it, he said it was 'Delicious'. This apple became very popular around the world.
**Granny Smith Apples (1850)**  
In Australia, Maria Anne Smith found a small apple tree in 1868. She took care of it and grew green apples that became famous. People called her 'Granny Smith' because she worked hard on her family’s farm. She believed that good things can come from what we think is useless.
**Modern Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from a few types that are chosen for their looks and how well they travel, not for their taste. Many old apple types are disappearing. In the UK, some gardeners keep old apple types alive, but in the US, many have been lost. People want more types of apples. We should all help to keep different kinds of apples and other foods safe for the future.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a travel company that offers exciting trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on visiting new and interesting places with fun and unique plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
We travel in small groups, usually with about 16 people. This makes it easier to learn about the places we visit. You will have a chance to meet local people and experience their culture. It is a great experience for all travelers.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport on our trips. Sometimes we travel by bus, train, boat, or even on foot. Each trip is special and shows the local area in a different way.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who like to try new things. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone who is healthy, fit, and open to new experiences. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, and the rest are individuals traveling alone.
**Activities and Interests**
Each trip is unique, so we have divided our adventures into 8 categories. Each category highlights special activities. Many trips focus on culture, visiting local people and historical sites. For example, you can visit Egypt, India, or Thailand.
**Wildlife Safaris**
Our wildlife safaris take you to amazing parks to see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can walk outside your vehicle and explore. You might track gorillas in Zaire or go canoeing in the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some have hotels.
**Cultural Encounters**
A special part of our trips is meeting different ethnic groups. You might meet the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to help promote understanding between cultures.
**Easy Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks in beautiful countryside. You can hike from village to village and stay in local homes or simple huts. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, and Thailand.
**Major Treks**
For strong walkers, we offer major treks in high mountains. These trips may involve walking at high altitudes and staying with local people or camping. We provide support, so you don’t have to carry heavy bags.
**Wilderness Experience**
Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These places offer unique experiences for adventurous travelers.
**Sail and River Journeys**
We also have relaxing holidays on boats. You can sail in Egypt or travel between islands in Greece. Our river trips can last from a few hours to several days, and no experience is needed. You will learn safety skills quickly.
Explore Worldwide offers many ways to travel and discover the world. Join us for an unforgettable adventure!

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners in his country. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is ten miles south of the equator. There is a mountain path that starts from a quiet road in Nairobi. This path leads to Mount Kenya, the highest mountain in Kenya. This beautiful but lonely place is called Nanyuk. For three years, it has been my home for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. But I had never trained with Kenyan runners before.
On my fourth trip to Kenya, I did something new. I ran in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This is where the best runners in Kenya prepare for big competitions. I was invited by the national team coach after I finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 metres race. I was behind three Kenyan runners and one Moroccan runner. It was a great chance for me.
Training at high altitude helps runners because it makes more red blood cells. This helps them carry more oxygen. Many Kenyan runners have been successful because of this. My first race in Africa was also special. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa, held in Nairobi. I finished behind 41 runners, and almost all of them were Kenyan. I felt I did okay!
I think Kenyan runners are successful for more reasons than just the high altitude. They have a simple and relaxed way of running. They enjoy competing and have a simple diet. I wanted to learn how they train. At the training camp, I found out more. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. It is a basic place with few comforts. The runners live with regular students and share rooms.
Every day, the runners have three training sessions: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the afternoon. The day starts at six in the morning. We wake up and meet the coaches for the morning run. The coach told us to run easy because we had a hard day ahead. We run about 40 kilometres each day, which is close to a marathon. On Sundays, we only run 20 kilometres, which is a nice break.
Life at the camp is simple. We wash our faces and brush our teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner are similar: ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we drive to a stream to wash off in the evening.
By the end of my time at the camp, I understood more about why Kenyan runners are successful. Their success is not just because of their genes or where they come from. I think it is also about their simple life in the mountains, their hard training, and their love for running. These are the real reasons why Kenya is so good at long-distance running.

**The Problems of Advertising**
Many people know that advertising is not doing well. This is not just because of the economy. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the economy got bad. The problems with advertising are serious and happen all over the world. 
Advertising has not changed with the economy. Advertisers think about big groups of people, but now there are many different groups. Even ads for big brands should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not. This is a big problem for advertising.
Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands, but not many. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For things like cars, you might only buy one every three years. You do not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. 
In total, you likely do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. But there are about 32,500 brands that are advertised. Most people only buy a small number of these brands. This means that a lot of advertising is not effective. 
When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that only about 1 in 16 ads are for brands they might buy. This means that 94% of the ads are not useful for them. 
Many people think they are not affected by advertising, but that is not true. Most people do not buy most of the brands they see in ads. There is always some waste in advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. 
Even though advertising can waste money, it can still be effective. Advertisers need to reach many people to find the few who will buy their products. They cannot know in advance who will buy. 
Good advertising can reach the right people better, but it can never be perfect. Even the best ads do not get a response from everyone. This is different from selling in person, where a salesperson can sell to every person they talk to. 
If an advertiser knows who will buy, they would not need to use ads. They could talk to those people directly. If an ad can get 1 million new customers, that is very good. For popular products, getting 2% of the population to buy is a big success. 
To make advertising work better, it needs to focus more on specific groups of people.

Charles Clover visits a very eco-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This town has some interesting places. One is Southwell Minster, a little-known old cathedral. It has special carvings of 'green' men made by craftsmen in the 1200s. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. This house is very green. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle waste into compost, and heat their home with waste heat from their appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday.
The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the old buildings in the town and was approved by planners, even though it is in a special area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, it is very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Inside, it is calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens windows and ventilation shafts to let fresh air in. 
The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for a long time. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called The Autonomous House. They wanted to build a house that did not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to not use mains water. They created special toilets, put rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean. They filter the water before using it. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they think strong detergents are not good for the environment.
Robert says, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is better for the environment, without living in the dark." The only old-fashioned part of the house is the hall, which has a fireplace and a staircase that goes up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, which cost about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use. Soon, they will add solar panels to generate more electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances, but it will make extra electricity. One day, they hope to charge an electric car with it.
The only heating in the house is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they only use when it is very cold. When I visited in February, Robert said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18C, which is lower than usual, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no draughts and everything was at the same temperature. He explained that people in the past were comfortable at lower temperatures because of their warm clothing. 
The secret of the house is that it is simple and easy to maintain. Most materials were bought from local shops and installed by local workers. This made the house cheap to build, costing the same as low-cost rental housing. Many building companies do not like this idea. 
**Questions:**
1. What is the name of the eco-friendly house built by Robert and Brenda Vale?
2. What do the Vales use for washing and drinking?
3. How do the Vales keep their house warm?
4. What did Robert say about the temperature in the house during winter?
5. Why is the house considered cheap to build?

The Camera and Fairies**
Arthur Conan Doyle created the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies in a garden. He believed these photos were proof that fairies really existed. He published the photos with an article, saying fairies are wonderful creatures.
In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the trick was simple. This shows that photography can be misleading. 
Today, we can change our digital photos with computer software. It is a myth that photography was always honest. From the beginning, when cameras started taking pictures, the reality was changed.

Blacksmiths**
For a long time, iron has been very important to people. The men who work with iron, called blacksmiths, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. 
However, by the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain. Heavy industry did not need them anymore, and new buildings did not use their beautiful ironwork. In the last 10 years, there has been a small revival of blacksmithing. More people are interested in decorative architecture and new styles of interior design. But much of the work still looks old-fashioned. Companies that make gates and balconies often call their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." 
You can find many trendy design stores selling rusty candlesticks and other items. Luckily, there are events happening soon to promote blacksmithing. The first event is an exhibition of ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). It opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We could be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently now." 
Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal. They can now bend, twist, and weld metal more easily. Dawson says, "These artists can now express themselves with this material." About 250 pieces of work are in the show, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the artists, but some will help the Association promote good ironwork. 
Dawson has made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says, "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow when it is hot. It’s like drawing with metal." Many artists love working with iron. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It’s magical because it is soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and strong." 
Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles that look like they come from scary castles. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another looks like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever." Iron gives people a lot of pleasure and a sense of security. It is likely that iron will be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we do not have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING**
I thought my friends would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She said, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I could not explain how I went from smoking a lot every day to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was strange for me too. 
I went to a stop-smoking session two months and three weeks ago. I did not plan to stop smoking, and I did not really want to. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking, and I still feel that way. My family is healthy, and I did not feel sick. I thought I was healthier than some of my friends who tried to live better.
On that Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about it. I said, "I will not try to stop. I am here to write, not to stop." I thought this was fair because I enjoyed smoking. It made me happy. The counselor looked at me like she understood. 
We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I did not want to. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. I began to think that stopping smoking could be a good thing. I felt strong thinking about not being a smoker. 
It was not hard to stop. The desire for nicotine went away after a few days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was not a problem. I was surprised that doing things at home on weekends was the hardest part. I realized that smoking helped me not feel bored. 
I do miss smoking a little, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is different. Eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, and waiting during a theater break are all moments when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For four years, I have asked my friends about her. When I tell them I am writing a biography of Dorothy Hodgkin, some say, "Isn't there one already?" If they do, I know they know her.
Dorothy Hodgkin won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964. She studied important things like penicillin and vitamin B12. She was a great scientist, but she also had a family. She had three children and a husband who was often away because of his job.
Many people think that scientists do not have interesting lives. Some scientists believe that their lives are boring to read about. But this is not true. Scientists can have exciting stories, just like artists or writers. 
Today, more scientists are sharing their lives with the public. For example, some scientists appear on TV shows or in advertisements. This helps people see that scientists are normal people too.
In the past, books about scientists were often dull. They did not talk much about the personal lives of scientists. But now, books are changing. They show scientists as real people with families and feelings. 
Dorothy Hodgkin loved her work. She was very dedicated to science. She worked hard to solve complex problems. But she also balanced her work with her family life. 
It is important for people to know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin. Understanding science can be as interesting as reading a good book or learning a new language. It is sad that many educated people do not know about the important work of scientists. 
**Questions:**
1. Who is Dorothy Hodgkin?
2. What did Dorothy Hodgkin win a Nobel Prize for?
3. How many children did Dorothy Hodgkin have?
4. Why do some people think scientists have boring lives?
5. How are scientists changing the way they share their lives with the public?

Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins has a special ability. She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers need her help because their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a well-drilling business. They use machines to drill wells, but Margaret only needs her hazel stick to find water. They are very successful, with more than 90% of their searches finding water.
This ability to find water is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special skill. There are different ideas about how it works. One idea is that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water. 
In recent years, many farmers have needed Margaret's help because of dry weather. Most of her customers are farmers who have lost their water supply. Some customers have holiday homes where it is too expensive to bring water from far away. Others are building golf courses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to avoid any waste getting into the water. The water she finds is usually clean, but she has to be careful because some areas have minerals like iron.
To start finding water, Margaret looks at a map and uses a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map, and it swings when she is over a place with water. After that, she walks in the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels something strange. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill.
Margaret holds the two ends of the stick and pulls them slightly apart. If the stick rises, it means there is water below. It is very important to drill in the right place. If they do not agree on where to drill, they will keep looking until they both agree.
Margaret is not alone in her work. Many people are interested in how she finds water. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special understanding of her surroundings. This skill helps her and her family continue their well-drilling business year after year.

**We changed lives for a day!** 
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something new! We helped four people do this. Here is what happened.
**A. Amanda's story**  
I am Amanda, 23 years old, and I have two daughters. I swapped lives with my friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. I had never been in a place like that before. It was dark and loud, and there were many people. It was very different from my hometown, and I was nervous! 
Being a mother is a busy job, but waitressing was harder! I had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when I tried, the drinks fell and spilled everywhere. I felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!
When the restaurant opened at 11:30 am, there was already a line of customers. I was worried about remembering their orders, but it was easy because everything was on a computer. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. I had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was very tired and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. One waitress told me it was a 'quiet' day! I never knew waitressing could be so tiring. I thought it was an easy job, but you need to be friendly and calm, especially when many customers come in. I am shy, and I don’t think I could work on a busy Saturday night. I was not happy with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very glad to go back to my children. Taking care of them seems easy after waitressing!
**B. Cindy's story**  
I am Cindy, and I was nervous about being a mother for a day, but I was also excited. Amanda warned me that her daughters were naughty, but I thought I could handle it. 
When Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of quiet time. I was wrong! Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.
At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started! They jumped on the couch and screamed loudly! I thought they would get tired, but I was wrong again. I thought I could keep up with them, but they were too much for me! 
After a lot of talking, I got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun began! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew they just wanted to come downstairs to watch TV, but it was tiring to talk to them all evening. I never knew taking care of two small children could be so hard. You don’t have time to think about yourself, and it feels like a big responsibility. Still, I really enjoyed the day.
**C. Rosemary's story**  
I am Rosemary, and I run a dairy farm. I usually wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am was nice! I was nervous about how to dress for school. I didn’t want to look like a farmer in front of the students. 
At school, I saw about 400 students at assembly. I hoped I would not stand out. Then I helped in a math class. The children worked in small groups, which was different from my school days. I also helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and wanted a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There is a lot to do before classes start again. 
I went to a staff meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, we had a silent reading lesson, which was nice, and then a French lesson. The children wanted to practice their French with me, which showed me I need to improve mine! Finally, we had Physical Education. I was very tired, but the children had so much energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers have more holidays, but I think I will stay with farming!
**D. Hilary's story**  
I am Hilary, and I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, but Rosemary had already been up for three hours! Rosemary has a big farm with many cows and sheep. She makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream to sell.
I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice cream. It was hard not to eat some! At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. I had to help a sheep that had fallen over. If they are not helped, they can die. 
After feeding the calves, I started milking the cows. It took two and a half hours, and Rosemary does this twice a day, every day! I felt lonely because I missed the children. Animals don’t talk back! The hardest part of the job is that you cannot take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, so it is hard to plan a break. Rosemary only gets about three days off this year. Farming seems nice, but it is very hard work. The money is not steady, and I would not like to depend on the weather.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is interesting that many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a special trumpet player from southern Sweden. He is 30 years old and is known around the world. He plays old music and new music. When you see him, he looks young and happy, just like the sound of the trumpet.
Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London. He also had a TV show about his work, filmed in London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo. When he was eight years old, his father, who did not play music, gave him a trumpet for Christmas. His father liked Louis Armstrong's music and wanted to give Hakan a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved the trumpet and played it all the time.
His mother found a trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra to give Hakan lessons. This teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw that Hakan had talent. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher. Bo loved the trumpet and always looked for new ways to play it. Hakan learned that every trumpet has small problems, and he learned to work with them.
From the beginning, Hakan had a special sound when he played. He always wanted to be a solo artist, not just play in an orchestra. He admired a French trumpet player named Maurice Andre and bought all his records. Hakan's parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player.
When Hakan was 15, he needed to choose where to study. His teacher wanted him to go to America, but it was too far. Instead, he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not as exciting as being a soloist. Hakan knew he played better than many other young players. 
At 17, he entered a competition in Paris. He only prepared for the first round but made it to the second round. He knew most of the pieces for that round too. In the final round, he had to play a piece that was very difficult for him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and realized that people listened to him.
Hakan is honest about his music. He does not want to explain how he connects with people through music because he believes it might ruin the magic of it. He thinks music has the power to move people. 
**Questions:**
1. Where is Hakan Hardenberger from?
2. How old is Hakan?
3. What did Hakan's father give him for Christmas?
4. Who was Hakan's first trumpet teacher?
5. What city did Hakan go to study in when he was 16?
6. Did Hakan win first prize in the competition?

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in a made-up country called Efica. It is a special tale about power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows the author's unique ideas. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. She usually would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who takes care of her old father and raised her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys do not talk about what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, does not explain why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son, and taking care of him becomes her main focus. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, and from this, they become friends. The author shows how people react when their lives change. He also shows how mothers feel they can never do enough for their children.
**C.** This book was nominated for the Booker Prize. It tells the story of a lonely island in the Scottish Orkney Islands and its people over a long time. The story includes important moments in Scottish history, imagined by a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears for a while and comes back after the Second World War, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.
**D.** After his big success, the author wrote a sequel that has the same humor and sharp observations about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter died, Aurora Greenway is now in her seventies and has a lively friend named Rosie Sunlap. Aurora still has her charming and kind personality, and Rosie helps her with her relationships. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is now important. The author skillfully shows the sadness that can be found in everyday life.
**E.** Six different people come together because of millionaire Logan Urquhart. He takes them on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit, to sail around the South Pacific islands. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during their journey. The story shows themes of memory and awareness through surprising images that can be both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what they do every day.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgery all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. Deciding when to do surgery can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed when I am operating, but I worry about what I will do the next day. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it works, it is amazing. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see patients and explain the surgeries. I like this part of my job. I try to comfort patients if they are upset, but I have to be quick. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my beeper. When I am on holiday, I worry about my patients for the first three days."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work. I arrive at 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, we meet to talk about our work and any problems. I work with a team of three senior designers, one partner, and one junior designer. My job is mostly about production, not just design. I get a brief from the client about what they want. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I show my ideas to the client. If they like them, we make plans and budgets. I also work with photographers and illustrators. I spend a lot of time managing people. I have to talk to many different people. When their work is done, I put everything together and send it to the printers. I often have many projects at once, which can be very stressful. I have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we try to go to the pub. I usually get home by 7:30 pm or later. It is hard for me to relax when I am busy."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am most days, but sometimes I wake up at 4:30 am or 5 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Because driving is a sitting job, I have to eat well and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area. Many jobs are booked in advance, so I can check the routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. But most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I take care of gardens we designed. We do some commercial jobs, but most are private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At about 11 am, we go to a cafe for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I have my office at home, so when I get back, I check messages and calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually meet them in the evening. We use old materials to make gardens look old. Sometimes, clients have strange ideas, but it is satisfying to see a garden we created. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the phone ring. I sleep well because my job is very physical, and I am always tired at the end of the day."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I help manage the building of bridges and a wall. I check that the workers are doing their jobs correctly and safely. I also help solve problems. The workers start at 6 am, so my first job is to find out what happened since I left the night before. I usually have paperwork to look at or questions to answer. I have lunch for about half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. I need to keep a good relationship with the workers because we check their work. I leave the site at about 6 pm and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I help customers who use our credit cards. I work on a program called Membership Rewards in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and then check my emails. I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan our advertising. I have many meetings, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different places in Europe once or twice a week. I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am. I check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone rings a lot after 10:30 am, and I have meetings to discuss projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know it is important for the artists, so I try to give good feedback. If I sign a band, we start working on their first album. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work at 7:00 pm and often go to concerts in the evening. I sometimes get home at 1:00 am.
**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule for the day. I enjoy showing customers furniture and helping them buy it. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000. I work with restorers to fix the furniture we buy. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette to stay updated on the business. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it takes me about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work in shifts. If I have an early shift, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start work at 7:00 am and control air traffic. I work for about an hour and a half at one station, then take a break and switch to another station. In winter, we manage about 1,000 flights a day. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new rules. This job is stressful, and I want to be a watch manager one day.
**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the electronic sales system and make sure someone is watching the cash register. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy helping them, but sometimes it can be hard when they want many books at once. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, publishers come to talk about new books. I need to make sure new books arrive on time. I finish my early shift at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work late and close the shop.
**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving at 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about my region. I assess financial risks for companies working abroad. I provide three services: a newsflash, a security forecast, and a travel information guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. I have deadlines to meet, so I work quickly. I travel to Africa three times a year for reports. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

Career Power**
**Get the Edge - Motivate Yourself at Work**
A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A leader is someone who inspires others. They help people change and grow. Being a leader is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says that leadership is about making things happen with people who are excited and interested. A good leader should be able to speak clearly and confidently. They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."
B. John van Maurik, who teaches a course on leadership, says that most people can be better leaders than they think. To become a leader, you need to find your hidden talents, develop them, and use them. In a way, we are all born to be leaders; we just need the right situation to grow. It is easy to see great leaders like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can be harder to see leadership in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.
C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and supported you. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and kept information from you. When things went wrong, they blamed you. The first leader was very good; the second leader was very bad.
D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new ideas. Micheal Shea, who wrote about leadership, says that a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad organization, whether it is a company, a sports team, or a country.
E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to do it. Find what you care about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy and take action.  
- Start thinking of yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is important. Recognize it.  
- Working together is good, but sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead yourself. See how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better and grow in your career.
F.  
- Leadership does not just happen. It grows when you take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, organize, and give praise.  
- Don’t think that everyone will like your way of leading right away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and available to important people. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

Films on Video**
**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent movies.**
**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense movie about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The funny and brave foreman Bud and his team remind us of heroes in old movies by Howard Hawks. The special effects are very good, but the dialogue and characters are not strong. The story feels like a simple B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on the book by James Jones about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is directed by Andrew Marton. Marton’s film is more traditional than Terrence Malick's new version, which is more poetic. Marton focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer, but Marton’s version has some good moments, like a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife.
**C. On Guard**  
This movie is based on a novel from 1875. It is a fun swashbuckler with a clever villain played by Fabrice Luchini. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, and Daniel Auteuil plays a moody character who is also a swordsman. The film uses many classic costume drama ideas, but it is entertaining.
**D. Character**  
This film is set in Rotterdam at the turn of the century. The detailed costumes and sets make it look like a museum. Jan Decleir plays a harsh bailiff named Dreverhaven, who is cruel to his tenants. His bad relationship with his son is the main story, but the film focuses too much on the details and not enough on the dark story.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released movie shows the skill of director Leone. The sound is very clear, and every noise is easy to hear. The story is harsh, and when it slows down, Morricone's great music makes it exciting again. The characters, the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), all seem equally bad as they travel across the West after the Civil War.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war movie has many famous stars. It has four directors and 23,000 extras, which is impressive. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for news about an invasion, are slow for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is a big project, it is better to watch on a big screen. Watching it on video is not as good.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is very interesting. The main character is a lawyer who is trying to start a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife when she is accused of killing her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending is surprising. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. The main character, Sigismondo, helps rich people in Italy during the Renaissance. He gets involved in politics and a murder case, but we believe he will find out who is guilty. The story is complicated and a bit long, but it is still very good.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is a tax inspector. She starts to investigate when a strange man dies near her. Even though she faces problems and the local detective does not approve of her, Leah is strong and smart. She is a great character.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to remove drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and there is more thinking than usual. It is always good entertainment from Parker.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a robbery at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The author's easy writing style and focus on strange human behavior make this a fun mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but most of the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. It has romance, money, and violence, making it a gripping suspense novel.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw shows actor Philip Fletcher as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains, but this time the story is not as good as his other works.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are looking for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the smart but troubled robber, making it better than an average detective novel.

Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He has a good job, but he decided to leave it and go backpacking. This summer, he quit his job and rented out his flat. He wants to travel in South East Asia for a year. Tim feels nervous about this decision. He has traveled before. After university, he spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When he came back, he fell in love, started a career, and bought a flat. He realized he was not happy just working for money. When he quit his job, he felt free again.
Many of Tim's friends are married and have children. They do not want to change places with him, but they envy his freedom. Tim is not in a relationship and does not have big career goals. He feels he should enjoy his freedom for his friends. But he is nervous about making plans. He worries about renting his home and where to go. He is also behind on his plans because he keeps putting things off.
Tim learned that many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel and change their lives. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says more people are realizing they can have adventures if they are brave and organized. Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny is ready to give up job security for this trip. He knows he might return to the same job, but he thinks it is worth the risk.
Matt, who just left the Army, traveled for a year to change his life. He wanted to learn to live differently. There are many reasons why people travel at this age. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says more people work on short-term contracts. If a contract ends, they have nothing to lose. Some companies even allow career breaks.
Dan Hiscocks, from Travellerseye, says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. If they are not happy, they know they can change things. Travel helps them think about what they want. Jennifer Cox believes this is a sign of a better society. People are asking themselves, "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher, is going to Central America for a year. He does not think he is running away; he wants to find something for himself. But he feels nervous about leaving his comfortable routine.
Tim also feels unsure about leaving his easy life. He thinks he might not have made this decision if he had a better boss. Jennifer Cox says many people travel after a big change in their lives, like a breakup or losing a job. Tim is excited about the next 12 months. He wants to enjoy life and make the most of his adventure. 
---
**Questions:**
1. How old is Tim Pozzi?
2. Where does Tim want to travel?
3. What did Tim do before he decided to travel?
4. Why does Tim feel nervous?
5. What did Danny and Tammy buy for their trip?
6. What does Angela Baron say about work today?
7. Why do many people travel at Tim's age?
8. What does Ben want to find during his trip?

Working from Home**
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt she did not know much about new technology. In this text, she shares how she changed her home into a good place to work.
Last Christmas, I turned 37 years old. I realized I needed to start my journalism career again. I looked at my resume and saw that I was still using old technology from the 1980s. Back then, I used a typewriter, and now I needed to learn how to use a computer. Many job ads asked for experience with desktop publishing, but I did not have any. I felt scared to use a computer.
I thought it would be hard to leave home to work, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer! We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for everyone. We started to learn about the Internet and began chatting with people from around the world. The children loved using the computer, and I set up a small office in the kitchen. I had a phone, a fax machine, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I could work from home and still take my children to school.
At first, I was nervous about using the computer. I thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I learned the basic skills I needed. It was easier than I thought. I started writing articles for a magazine, and now I feel proud of my work.
The computer helped me become more organized. I used spreadsheets to keep track of money and made invoices easily. With the Internet, I could research stories and talk to other journalists online. 
However, working from home has some problems. I sometimes feel lonely because I do not see many people. There are also distractions at home, like chores and sharing the computer with my children. 
Many people in my neighborhood are also using computers for work. A report says that most home workers are educated and own a personal computer. I feel I am doing well with my computer skills. One day, I hope to send my articles to a newspaper in Australia or even start my own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless!

**The Tartan Museum**
The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has modern buildings that look like cheese wedges. The outside of the museum is very big and easy to see. It has a tall yellow tower and a garden hanging from the roof. 
Last winter, people had different opinions about the museum's design. Some people thought it was beautiful, while others were not sure about it. Now, the inside of the museum is almost ready to open. 
The museum tells many stories about Scotland's history. It has important objects, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants the museum to be fun and interesting for everyone, not just experts. He believes that the museum should show the truth about the past.
Visitors will see many displays with explanations and pictures. There are also computers to help tell the stories. The museum has many rooms that connect to each other, with light coming in from the windows. 
There is a special area for children called the Discovery Centre. A group of kids helped create this space. They wanted to have fun with the displays. The top floor has a gallery that changes every three years. It shows objects that are important to Scottish life in the twentieth century, like electric guitars and toys.
Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The museum's modern design is nice inside, but some people wonder if it is in the right place.

The end of print newspapers may take some time. "Transition" is a nice word. It means moving from one place to another. Some people may be scared of change, but it can also be good. 
Now, newspapers are trying to move to the online world. This is not easy. Many people know that print newspaper sales are going down, but visits to their websites are going up. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, but their websites are getting more visitors.
However, there are some interesting facts. A survey showed that the total number of newspapers sold around the world actually went up by 1.1% last year. In some places, like Asia, sales increased a lot. Also, news magazines are doing well, with a 5.4% increase in sales.
When it comes to books, e-readers like Kindle are very popular, and their sales are high. But when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books, they found that sales were only down by 0.4%. This means people are buying both e-books and paper books.
Many people think young people do not read newspapers anymore, but this is not true. A survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read the main national newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, print sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop is only 7%. In France, it is just 3.1%.
Some experts thought that online advertising would help newspapers, but now that advertising is going down. Many US newspapers have started to charge for online access. The best way to get readers is to offer both a print copy and online access together. Print newspapers help sell online subscriptions, and they make much more money from ads than online ads.
However, it is hard for newspapers to keep both print and online versions. It costs a lot of money and is complicated. But print newspapers are still important for getting noticed in the busy online world. 
**Questions:**
1. What does the word "transition" mean in the text?
2. Are print newspaper sales going up or down?
3. How much did the total number of newspapers sold around the world increase last year?
4. What is happening to e-reader sales?
5. How many young people aged 15 to 35 read national newspapers?
6. Which country has the biggest drop in print sales?

**Photographing People**
People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually more exciting than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be hard. The photographer must pay attention to how people move, their gestures, and their expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking pictures of groups, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can have some people sitting or kneeling in front so you can see all their faces.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting they find a comfortable position, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is clear you are. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel shy. You may need to guide them to look at the camera.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo looks better if the person is looking at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural, as if you are watching them without them knowing.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
The expressions and gestures of a person tell us a lot about them. A laughing child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for common expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up.
**G. Situation Interest**  
The background of a photo can add more interest. Make sure the background does not take attention away from the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger compared to the background.
**H. Interaction**  
Good photos can happen when people are talking, laughing, or working together. Look for moments of connection, like eye contact or a handshake.
**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken on trips. To show both the person and the place, use a wide-angle lens and step back to include the background. Make sure the people are close enough to be seen clearly.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone you met on holiday, ask them to pose nicely. For family photos, candid shots of events can be more fun and lively than formal poses. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is an artist who creates trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings look real but are actually tricks for the eyes. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about Sarah.
Not many artists do not sign their work, but Sarah is one of them. She believes that the work is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and does not like to talk about herself. When asked if she wants to be photographed, she looks worried.
After a while, Sarah feels more comfortable, and the interview becomes fun and interesting. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she studied drawing at art school and worked in graphic illustration. She did not enjoy illustration, so she started working with a special decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and she loved it. She decided to work on her own, even though she was not sure what would happen.
Sarah's skills in observing details helped her become a good trompe-l'oeil artist. She says, "People often ask me where they can learn trompe-l'oeil. But no one can teach you.
