Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation." She believes that you should always keep learning. She is honest about her weaknesses, saying, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." 
When she had a big job to paint a ceiling at Lulworth Castle, she felt confused about the measurements. She thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" Sarah often talks about herself in the third person, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"
Sarah's trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special. She has many important clients and creates works inspired by buildings. For example, she made a trompe-l'oeil dining room that looks like a Venetian palace. She knows that once people understand the trick, they might lose interest. So, she believes her art must do two things: first, it must trick you, and second, it must keep your attention and make you think.
Sarah loves working with her clients. She says, "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born." Some clients know exactly what they want, while others do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their ideas. Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.
Sarah is thankful for her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, which is why she is always busy. Even though she does not like to talk about herself, she believes her work should be seen. She says, "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout." 
In the end, Sarah's art is unique and deserves more attention.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman talks about the important "people skills" that help us succeed at work.
A. The rules for work are changing. Now, we are judged not only by how smart we are or by our training but also by how well we manage ourselves and work with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to show who will do well at their job and who may not. These new rules are important for our future jobs. They are different from what we learned in school. Doing well in tests is not as important anymore. Now, we need to have good social skills and personal qualities, like being able to take initiative, understand others, adapt to change, and persuade people. These skills are called emotional intelligence.
B. In a time when job security is low, personal qualities are becoming more important at work. For many years, people have talked about these qualities using different names, like "character" or "soft skills." Now, we have a better understanding of these skills, and we call them "emotional intelligence." This means being able to understand and manage our own feelings and the feelings of others. In our work, emotional intelligence includes being aware of ourselves, controlling our emotions, staying motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means "being nice," but it can also mean being honest, even when it is uncomfortable. It is not about showing all our feelings but managing them so we can work well together.
C. More businesses are realizing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. The more complicated the job, the more we need emotional intelligence. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard for them to use their knowledge and skills. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for doing well in any job.
D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we live and learn. Studies show that most people get better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us in our jobs, especially now when having a stable job is not easy. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if we ignore the human side of work, nothing else will work as well.

'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones make it easy to take pictures of news events. Social media has changed how people share these pictures. Now, some journalists look at social media for images when news happens quickly. However, some reporters use pictures from users without asking for permission. There are rules that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or if there is strong public interest, but people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event, so user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure that people are paid for their work and that they always ask for permission.'

Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**
Acupuncture is a type of medicine that is over two thousand years old. It comes from China and is part of traditional Chinese medicine. This system also includes using herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is often used to help with pain. Many doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists in the West use it for pain relief.
**A. What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**  
Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. They say that energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows in the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to organs in the body. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel weak or sick. An acupuncturist checks the flow of Qi by feeling pulses on your wrist, looking at your tongue, and asking about your health, eating, and sleeping habits. They use very thin needles to help the Qi flow better.
**B. Acupuncture Points**  
Acupuncture points are connected to the meridians and may not be near where you feel pain. People often feel a gentle ache or tingling when the needle is used. This can be done by hand or with a machine. Acupuncturists say this feeling means the needle is working.
**C. Scientific Explanations**  
Doctors in the West believe acupuncture can help with pain, even if they do not follow traditional Chinese medicine. They think that acupuncture can block pain signals or release natural pain-relieving substances in the body.
**D. Types of Pain Treated**  
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. It can help with back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain and pain in terminally ill patients.
**E. Modern Use of Acupuncture**  
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China believe in acupuncture. In China today, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, and it can help reduce pain. Some people recover from surgery faster with acupuncture.
**F. Effectiveness of Acupuncture**  
It is hard to study acupuncture, but some trials show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with chronic pain. Acupuncturists say it usually takes six to seven visits to feel real relief, but some people feel better after just two or three visits.
**G. A Different Way to Look at Pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They spend time understanding the pain and what might be causing it, like weather or how it feels. This is different from how many doctors approach pain.
**H. Choosing an Acupuncturist**  
Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. Traditional acupuncturists believe their methods can lead to better healing. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist, and they should refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems calm and confident, but she is actually shy. She says that Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is like her if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James likes to write alone. She needs quiet time to write and can do it anywhere if she has privacy.
P.D. James does not agree that she is the best crime writer in Britain, even though many people read her 12 detective novels. She loves the books of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she likes some male authors too, like Graham Greene.
P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there, who was a student. Life was not easy for her. Her husband, Connor, was very sick after the Second World War. P.D. James had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband’s parents helped take care of the girls during this tough time.
While working for the National Health Service, she used her good organizational skills. She managed five clinics. Then, she worked for 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and then in juvenile crime. While working in forensic science, she saw many dead bodies, but she was not interested in death itself. She liked the challenge of writing crime stories. 
P.D. James did not want to write about her own life. She thought writing detective stories was a good way to learn how to write serious novels. She realized that she could follow the rules of a detective story and still write a meaningful book about people. She believes that solving a crime brings order to chaos and shows that life is important, even if it is not perfect.

The pen is stronger than the psychoanalyst. The study of handwriting to show a person's character is becoming more popular. If you apply for a job in some countries, you will likely be asked to give a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help show some illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can show emotional problems.
Many big companies now use graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not sure about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if a person should focus on arts or sciences and if they are honest or tricky."
According to Ms. Marne, graphology can help find possible criminal behavior. She says, "Criminals often have bad handwriting. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional problems. This can show in childish handwriting and in writing letters many times." She believes she can tell if people are honest or not. 
Ms. Marne says handwriting can show if someone is under a lot of stress or has violent thoughts. It can even help predict if someone might think about suicide. Heart and lung problems can also be seen in handwriting. She explains, "You cannot make a diagnosis from one sample, unless the writing is very shaky. But if the handwriting changes over time, it could mean something serious is happening."
A big emotional problem can also change a person's signature for a short time. Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. For example, people who write with letters that connect are often clever and tricky. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity. Original handwriting shows confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing shows a person who is lonely. Very small signatures can mean a person feels shy or inferior. 
Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study to analyze handwriting well, and this needs empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She thinks it is more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can show a person's history and emotional problems without asking them questions.
However, there is not much strong evidence to support these ideas. Some psychiatrists are very critical. They say handwriting is just a result of education and the way people are taught to write, and it does not mean anything else.

Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
**Office A: Advertising Agency**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office is very simple. It has no central heating and no mechanical ventilation. The windows open to the street. It is surprising that this office works well, but the small team of seven people seems happy. They change the office temperature by opening doors or using electric heaters, just like at home. This may be the reason they are happy.  
*Ergonomist:* The furniture does not match. Some chairs are old and broken, and they do not help good posture. However, the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations. This variety helps them avoid tiredness and boredom.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The staff likes the different types of work and the office space. They say the office is "just the right size" – small enough to know what others are doing, but big enough to work alone. The office looks nice and fun, and it feels efficient and creative.
**Office B: News Service**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable. The air quality is good, and there is a No Smoking policy.  
*Ergonomist:* The company has good chairs and lighting. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. The walls are plain and dull.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The walls have only a few planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have worked there for at least five years, and they get along well. The office could be better if the desks were arranged to share information more easily.
**Office C: Bank**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office gets mixed feelings from workers. It feels like being in a glass box. The air is not stale, even with smokers nearby.  
*Ergonomist:* The office is very standard and not inspiring. The desks are okay, but some chairs are not good for computer work.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The staff helps each other and uses technology well. There are many awards on display. The office is busy, but the colors make it feel a bit dark.
**Office D: Newspaper**  
*Building Health Consultant:* This office has many problems. The air conditioning does not work well, and the temperature changes a lot. The space is messy, and there is not enough desk space. It is very dusty.  
*Ergonomist:* The furniture is not good for a modern office. Many chairs are old and do not help workers who are shorter.  
*Occupational Psychologist:* The office has old chairs and dirty carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. There are many smokers. When we visited, people seemed stressed and were not talking much. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular in America. People chew 12 million sticks of gum every day. It is a simple food and must follow rules from the American Food and Drug Administration. Each stick of gum has less than ten calories. 
Today, most gum is made with synthetic materials. These materials help keep the flavor and make the gum soft. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like substance from the mastic tree, which grows in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and make their breath fresh. 
American colonists learned to chew gum from the Native Americans in New England. They chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States sold spruce gum. This was the first commercial chewing gum in America. 
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s when people discovered chicle. Chicle is a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. Gum made from chicle is smoother and more elastic. This created a big industry for chewing gum. However, it is hard to grow sapodilla trees, so many gum makers now use synthetic materials instead.
Today, there are few chicle gatherers, called chicleros. They work hard to collect chicle from trees. They walk for miles in hot and humid conditions. There are dangerous snakes and insects in the forest. Chicleros climb trees to collect the white sap and carry it back to a camp. At the camp, they boil the sap until it becomes sticky and forms bricks. 
Life at the camp is tough. Chicleros eat a simple diet of maize and drink local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.
As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have started using synthetic materials to save money. Gum makers also find new ways to sell their products. They say that chewing gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces tooth decay. Chewing gum can help your saliva flow, which protects your teeth. 
Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors for gum. Some new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**
A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The hotel has a calm and peaceful atmosphere with Indian decorations. The Ghanerao family has lived there for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel has basic facilities, like hot water from a bucket, but this makes it special.
B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
My favorite hotel is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After climbing a glacier, I walked down and was surprised to see the hotel in beautiful countryside. It is very high up and surrounded by nature. After a long climb, it was amazing to find such luxury, with a man playing music on the piano.
C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in the south-west of Mauritius. The road to the hotel goes along the coast with empty beaches. The hotel is big and offers free water sports, but you can find peace on the nine kilometers of private beach. If you swim a little way out into the ocean, you can hardly see the hotel. In the evening, when everyone is gone, it feels very calm and far away from everything.
D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a beautiful view of the Caribbean Sea. It is quiet and high up, with open rooms looking out at the Pitons. The hotel has a colonial style with wooden furniture and four-poster beds.
E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. It is only an hour by boat. There are no cars, just horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is made of wood, painted white with red domes. It is a little old but still charming.
F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, there is a beautiful seventeenth-century chateau. It has a moat with swans and 20 different rooms, some with four-poster beds. There are special weekend rates for two nights with breakfast and dinner, plus complimentary champagne.
G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Nairobi. It is popular with travelers who are resting after a safari. Guests often decide to stay longer because of the beautiful gardens and good food. The hotel has many trees and buildings on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to watch the sunset while enjoying a drink and a hearty dinner.
H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido has welcomed many famous people. It used to be a monastery and is now a beautiful hotel. It is still very nice and offers simple, delicious food. The hotel has lovely rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. One minute into her visit to the Globe Hotel, things are already not good. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not see Sue and Christopher. Sue says, "She hasn’t even looked at us. This is very bad." 
Sue has been an inspector for 11 years. She expects better from the Globe Hotel because it has three red stars. This means it is one of the best hotels. But even before they enter, Sue feels something is wrong. The door from the parking lot is not manned, and the hallway is long and empty. 
When they finally get to the reception, the receptionist says, "We have no record of your booking." There are 15 rooms in the hotel, but 12 are empty. One room is on the top floor, but it is not good. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe. 
Sue remembers when she started her job. People called her "The Woman in Black," but she never wore black and did not think she was tough. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. He says, "We think there is a blocked drain." 
Sue suggests that he should not let guests go into the room with the bad smell. She says it is better to take them to another lounge. Robin agrees and takes notes. He has worked at the Globe for only five months and is trying to understand Sue's advice. 
Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good work. The dinner is also good, so the hotel keeps its two-rosette food rating. Robin asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue replies, "Do not serve a dessert that falls apart." 
Sue's job is to tell the hotel what is wrong. Sometimes, people complain about her. She remembers a woman who said Sue got her son fired. Sue only told the truth: the son served her pie with his fingers. 
Sue must write a report about her visit. The hotels pay for her to help them improve. It is good for Robin to hear that Sue will not take away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems are fixed. Robin smiles but looks worried. "We will look forward to that," he says. 
**Questions:**
1. What is Sue Brown's job?
2. How long has Sue been a hotel inspector?
3. How many rooms are empty at the Globe Hotel?
4. What did Sue suggest to the hotel manager about the bad smell?
5. Who did Sue praise for their good work?

Doug Scott is a mountaineer who writes about climbing the highest mountains on each continent, called the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in his life. Here are his climbs:
A. **Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave before reaching the top. They talked about sleeping bags, which Doug thought was strange because they were alone. He felt cold and worried about frostbite. Doug felt calm and confident because Dougal was with him. He found a good rhythm to reach the summit.
B. **Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal carried their equipment to the base. They realized the climb was hard. They followed a route from 1967 but chose a new route to the top. They carried everything on their backs. After three days, they were tired and cold. Finally, they reached the summit and felt happy.
C. **Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. Instead, they got a free ride to Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle and had trouble finding water. They were happy to find a rock pool. They tried to climb a steep wall but decided to take a safer route to the top.
D. **Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca. They met a guide named Phil who invited them to climb a different route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The wind was strong, but they reached the summit and camped nearby. They met a group planning to climb the Seven Summits, and Doug thought about doing the same.
E. **Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif was possible if he guided enough people. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. The sun was always shining, and it was very quiet. On December 7, they climbed to the summit in strong winds and very cold temperatures. They were happy but could not see much because of the storm.
F. **Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team met in St Petersburg. They took a cable car to a high point on Elbrus. After two days, they climbed in strong winds and icy conditions. They thought they reached the top but found there was more to climb. They returned to their camp and then went down the mountain.
G. **Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On this climb, Doug wanted to explore a new route and meet the local Dani people. They were warned about dangers but decided to go. On May 12, they climbed and reached the summit by 11 am. Doug felt proud to complete his seventh summit.
**Questions:**
1. What is the name of the highest mountain in Asia that Doug climbed?
2. Who was Doug's climbing partner on Mt. Everest?
3. What did Doug and Dougal carry on their backs while climbing Mt. McKinley?
4. Why were Doug and Paul happy when they found a rock pool on Kilimanjaro?
5. What did Doug do to climb Vinson Massif?
6. What did Doug's team use to get to a high point on Elbrus?
7. What did Doug want to do on his climb of Carstensz Pyramid?

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today. It affects our clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley shares some fashion trends for this year.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**
Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says, "People should avoid stiff and frilly dresses. Simpler styles are better." Ned has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress. He also designs long evening dresses in new colors and fabrics. For those who like classic styles, he has a navy-blue summer suit, which has been popular for many years.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not study jewellery. She started designing rings when she could not find one she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Now, many famous people want her jewellery. She uses large semi-precious stones in gold to make beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings. Recently, she started using diamonds. She says, "I wanted a diamond, so I began to work with them."
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**
Lily Grimson started her handbag business four years ago. She only took a short art and design course. Two of her bags were chosen for a big design exhibition. All of her bags are handmade in the UK. Grimson bags are not just for carrying things; they are stylish and made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk.
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**
Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people have had their hair styled by him. He says, "Most women want hair that looks real and is easy to manage." He wants his clients to look natural, not like they just came from a salon. His services are expensive, costing £250 for the first visit, and there is a long waiting list. He also sells his own hairdryers and styling tools for people to use at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a flower consultant for supermarkets and restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and used to be a teacher. Her modern flower arrangements have won many awards, and she has started her own London Flower School. She has also given lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, "Flower arrangements are simpler now. Keep them simple and strong, and don’t use too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, all the flowers should be the same type." 
---
**Questions:**
1. What type of dresses does Ned Ingham design?
2. Why did Sally Quail start designing her own rings?
3. How long has Peter Little been a hairdresser?
4. What does Penny Pratt do besides running her flower shop?
5. What is special about Lily Grimson's handbags?

The Merrion Hotel**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was made from four old houses and took almost two years to build. The hotel has modern technology to help both the staff and the guests.
The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know the guests' names. For special details about the guests, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give good service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but it will save money in the future. MacCann likes how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music during their first stay, the hotel will have that music ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can set it between 14°C and 25°C. 
The hotel also has special technology for business guests. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel is ready for new technology, so they have extra cables for future upgrades. They rent televisions and DVD recorders, so they can change them for newer models when needed.
Even with all this technology, the hotel wants guests to feel comfortable. There are 145 large and cozy bedrooms. The hotel also has a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.
The food at the hotel is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has made a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel benefits from having a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

Susan Shepherd and Her Garden**
Susan Shepherd is an artist. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden has many flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. 
There are two long flower beds along a path in the garden. The colors and shapes of the flowers are very nice. The previous owners of the garden were good gardeners. They left many plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas. But when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint individual flowers instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she picks flowers and takes them to her studio. She does not paint everything at once. She takes one flower, paints it for a few days, and then takes another flower. Sometimes it can take a couple of years to finish a painting.
Spring and early summer are her busiest times. This is when the tulips and poppies bloom. Susan loves how flowers change over time. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful. At first, they may seem boring, but they become interesting.
Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She liked wildflowers that grew in difficult places, like rocks or cliffs.
Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they do not break anything. 
Susan is busy preparing for two art exhibitions. She has a lot of flowers to paint, but she finds it hard to work in the garden. She now has another gardener to help her. However, she knows that to paint flowers well, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**
Many trees in Brackham were damaged in the big storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This change made the town look very different, and some people were not happy about it. One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, who was the head of the local police. But during the storm, Pelham was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and felt tightness in his chest. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he thought he was too important to go. He tried to keep working, but this made him forget things and made him angry.
Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. Soon, he got medicine and went home to Molly, who sent him to bed. On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the night. Pelham was too sick to understand. Later, he asked if the house was damaged. When he learned it was not, he felt relieved and went back to bed.
On Saturday, when the medicine started to work, Pelham got up and saw that the living room looked very different without the walnut tree. Their big house had a nice garden, and Pelham was happy he bought it. The garden made them feel private. Before, the walnut tree made the living room look nice with light and shadows. But now, without the tree, the room was too bright, and the old furniture looked bad. 
The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams. 
“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said to Molly. But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed happy. “I’ve been saying this since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

Living in the Valley**
We had lived in our valley for sixteen months when we first saw the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, before winter started. Until then, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. 
In the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we felt only some strong gusts of wind; the trees moved, but their branches stayed strong. We knew we should worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really scare us. The river, called the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, was what worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams.
Soon, the snow started to melt. Day by day, we saw dark clouds gather over the hills. These clouds looked dangerous and warned us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to overflowing.
Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small waterfall as the water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water rushed down towards our cottage. Just a few meters from our home, the stream was deeper than we had ever seen, moving quickly against its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below the dam. Luckily, the dam held, and the water began to go down.
In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually everything is fine. The water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with just a little overflow sometimes. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel safe in our home.

Film critic Mark Adams thinks about his work over the last ten years for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was his first real job. Before this, he wrote reviews for books in other newspapers, films for a magazine, and did some work for the radio. This is how he met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. Tom also worked in radio and television. He hired Mark, but Tom was not a full-time journalist, so he did not choose his staff carefully.
At first, Tom wanted a team of critics to cover different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a lunch every week to talk about what to write about. It felt like a dream for Mark to be part of a new newspaper. He thought it was strange that a new paper could start in a busy market. He even thought a rich person was helping him and pretending to hire him. The first time he saw someone reading his review in the newspaper on the London Underground, he felt very shy.
Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned, so they talked by phone instead. Mark found that people liked to read reviews from critics who focused on one subject. So, he chose to write about films. Without Tom's help, they would not have the current way of working, where Mark writes a long article each week about one film. He likes this way of working. He did not want to be a standard film critic who has to watch every new film. That would make him tired and unhappy.
Mark thinks about his role as a critic. He believes people choose films based on stars, ads, or the director. People usually stick to what they like. Someone who does not like westerns is unlikely to watch one just because of a review. So, if a film review is not a guide for buying tickets, what is it? Mark does not feel he must be "right" about a movie. He does not think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. His job is to share his opinion. He does not want to be a judge.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 
Melanie Sears is a teenager who loves sports. She is looking for a training partner for triathlons, especially a girl. She wants someone who enjoys running long distances (15 kilometers), swimming in cold water, and cycling long distances (100 kilometers). It is important to be able to do all three sports without taking a break.
Triathlons are becoming very popular in the Olympics. Many people watch athletes swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. It looks hard, but Melanie enjoys it. She started doing triathlons when she was 14 years old. 
In her first triathlon, she won the junior section, but she was the only junior there. She felt confident and entered the National Championships. She swam fast and ran fast, but she got lost and cycled 20 kilometers too far. She cried while running, but she did not give up. She wants to keep trying.
Melanie is very determined. She trains hard, even when it is difficult. She was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships this year, finishing 13th. She is working hard to improve her cycling because she is slower at it than swimming and running. 
Melanie is asking her parents to buy a new bike for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships. The bike costs £2,000, but there is a special deal. 
Her training takes a lot of time, so she does not have a social life. She says, "I don't go to parties. After swimming for two hours, I just want to sleep." But she still talks to the other girls on her team about their training times.
Melanie has tried shorter triathlons, like the "sprint," where you swim 750 meters, cycle 20 kilometers, and run 5 kilometers. She wants to try even harder events, but she has no one her age to train with. 
**Questions:**
1. What sports does Melanie do in a triathlon?
2. How old was Melanie when she started doing triathlons?
3. What happened when Melanie entered the National Championships?
4. Why does Melanie not have a social life?
5. What does Melanie want to improve in her training?

The Collectors**
Amanda Roy writes about collecting things and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults collects something. Collecting is a world of passion and joy. But if you want to collect, remember this: only collect things you love.
People have collected items for a long time. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.
I have collected many things in my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a cold, windy place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum. The museum had many interesting objects collected by people in the past. I loved looking at these objects. 
Many adults also enjoy collecting. Some people collect because it is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, I just enjoy it. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful items. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had more than 4,000 paintings. 
You do not need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected many different things, like tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I convinced another collector to give me a special tulip. I planted it and took care of it, but one year it disappeared – stolen by another collector. 
I once collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. The next morning, I looked at the remains of my home and felt very sad.
I find it interesting how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet can be very valuable. As small items become popular, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you still have the original boxes. (I threw away the boxes and the toys!)

My Line of Work**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I put together temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. I read about the subject of the exhibition and talk to important people to find out the main ideas. I decide what objects and pictures to show. I make sure the public can understand the exhibition. I plan activities like workshops and shows. I also work with engineers and electricians to keep visitors safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people.
**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, learning the best routes to take. I help when there are disagreements, like if a right turn is allowed at a junction. When students are close to the test, I give them a simple route. I tell them they must find another way if the road is closed. This helps them think.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I usually work by the sea. I work with schools and run courses for people who manage the coast. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the life in the ocean. This often changes their views. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. However, I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money and resources.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is varied. I make sure our publishing program meets market needs and keep about 300 books in stock. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I must respond carefully. I discuss future projects and sales with my co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is that there is too much administration, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text:**
We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some changes to it, but they did it carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. 
"How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were in the same school, which is why we call Strafe by his last name. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. 
"How nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are coming because she is usually waiting in the hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. She called our rooms by names: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when few people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of small details like that; her husband takes care of repairs. 
"Welcome," Mr. Malseed said, coming into the hall from the kitchen. He was smiling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I could tell the others felt our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year," she said, making everyone laugh again. 
Arthur took us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not for too long because we were still tired from the trip. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others going down to the beach. 
In the morning, we would walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because we had done the same things for many years. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. Sarah works for a company that helps visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. This is her second year as a chalet girl.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is not a long-term job, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two. She meets many interesting people every week.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she thinks is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.
After skiing, Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. Good guests can make her week better, but some weeks are not as good.
Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's and maybe Dick's T-Bar. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.
On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., she finishes cleaning and prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests have many questions.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. She gets a ride back to the chalet from the ski shop staff. Then it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she has a drink after work, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her hair was messy but framed her pretty face. Seymour was surprised that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research about the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions on the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class who visited the factory years ago. Seymour showed them how he made gloves, especially at the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove using hot brass hands. Marie called them the "pancake hands" because they looked strange.
Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come to your shipping department?" He explained, "They come to the tannery. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us. My grandfather, father, and I worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour said, "You should go if you want to write about leather. I can help you visit one. They are old places. The technology is better now, but it is still similar to what it was hundreds of years ago. It is hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries. They found 6,000-year-old tools for tanning in Turkey. The first clothes were made from animal skins that were tanned by smoking."
Seymour continued, "My father knows a lot about leather. You should talk to him. He can talk for two days about gloves. Glovemen love their work. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" Rita replied, "I can't say I have." Seymour asked, "Never seen anything made?" She said, "I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." Seymour laughed. He liked her spirit and eagerness to learn. His daughter was much taller than Rita, but Rita reminded him of Marie. 
He remembered how Marie would come home from school, full of what she learned. She wrote everything down in her notebook and remembered it all. Seymour said, "Let's do something fun. We will show you how to make a pair of gloves from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is it a tough job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.
**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But there is one small problem - she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so small with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings, and making travel plans. She did not apply for this job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance and took a secretarial course at night. Five years later, she became a personal assistant.
**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because he loves golf. However, there are some problems. He earns a small flat fee and a part of the winnings. He usually makes between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You are not just carrying bags. You give advice and try to understand the course," he says. His skills in accounting were noticed by European Tour Productions, and they made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes the statistics of each day's play, which are important for TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers.
**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food in the best restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "If people can pay, it is their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His friend, who was an editor, offered him a food column because he is a good cook. At that time, Martin was working in advertising and it helped him earn extra money. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant I would earn less money," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay healthy by cycling to the nearest tube station.
**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. "Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's story." Where do his ideas come from? "It is not easy; I have to work hard on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I do not wake up very early. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy that part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story brick building. Around the building, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust looked like golden mountains and covered the yard down to the blue lake. 
One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored. They followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down." Without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust. He rolled around and laughed. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards!" 
His friends looked down from the roof, scared. But one by one, they jumped down and landed in the sawdust, smiling with relief. In the warm sunlight, they lay on the sawdust pile and told jokes. Then one friend said, "Let’s go back up to the roof and jump down again." 
They were not very excited, but they went back up. They jumped off the roof one by one until only Michael was left. The others were down below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What’s wrong with you?" 
Michael wanted to jump down too, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten and then jump, but he couldn’t. His friends started to laugh at him. They were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you’re a coward! Do you think we will sit here all night?" they shouted. When he did not move, they began to walk away, still shouting. 
Michael felt sad and alone. He stared at the ground for a long time. He stayed on the roof while the sun went down. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped off the roof. He fell into the sawdust and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. 
As he lay there, he wondered why he could not jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed. He was late for dinner. His stepmother said, "You should be able to get home on time. If you won’t come home, you can stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with soft skin and a little grey in her hair. She looked serious, but Michael did not really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change but don’t know how? Kitty Doherty has some good advice. Many people who want to change their job go to a careers adviser. First, you write a short history of yourself. Then, you take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers and any training you might need.
I tried Career Analysts, a big organization that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I reminded myself that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard to understand. They included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was a bit sad to learn that I did not do well in the science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse! However, it was good to hear that I made the right choices about journalism.
Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. She said, "Losing my job was a good chance to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. "I didn’t know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of training in design and my money situation," she said. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she decided to use her current skills and find a job that suited her better than insurance. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she really wanted to do. She has sent six friends there, and they are all happy with the service.
Some people feel they would not have made changes without help. Juliet Greene, 26, visited Career Counselling Services and made important decisions. "After working at a big bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I didn’t know what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, and they showed I was interested in sciences," she said. "I had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped me remember what I said. After the fourth meeting, I listened to the results and decided I wanted to study geology. I plan to start a degree in it later this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the money. I am much happier now."
However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I didn’t know what to do. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. I got many new ideas, but I rejected them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself. You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I told a friend the same things, they would give me similar advice."

Fun at the Dentist's**
If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make a place where people feel safe. That is why he does not wear a white coat. He believes that dental visits should be relaxing and enjoyable.
Many people think dental visits are painful or very serious. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed and happy, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ideas is to use virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular." Patients wear the headsets during their check-up. They sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while Jerome checks their teeth. The headset also shows a special camera view of their mouth.
Most patients like this part of their visit. The office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. He knows that bad smells can make people nervous.
Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, but he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation ideas are important, but good treatment is the most important. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a little strange, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental methods. He says, "When you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too." He wants to change the serious way of British dentistry. 
When a patient arrives, Jerome quickly goes to help. He offers the patient a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video they want to watch, and leads them to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a nice beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

Chocolate and Its History**
Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In Britain, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is about 8% of all chocolate sales in the year. People eat more chocolate at Christmas than at any other time.
The cacao plant, which is used to make chocolate, was first grown by the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South America, Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. The fruit of the cacao tree is big and has 20-40 seeds inside. When these seeds are dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, these are often called cocoa beans, but this is a mistake from the 17th century.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language. They added spices to this drink for special occasions. When the Spanish found this drink, they liked it better with cinnamon and sugar. However, it took a long time for this recipe to reach the rest of Europe.
In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in European cities where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, people made chocolate drinks from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, a man named CJ van Houten from the Netherlands created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. 
The first chocolate bar we know today was made in 1847 by a company in Bristol called Fry and Sons. They mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid chocolate bar. A Swiss company later added milk to make milk chocolate.
In the late 1800s, French companies were very popular in the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract customers with a French name. Then, in 1905, Cadbury created the Dairy Milk bar, which became very popular because of clever advertising that linked it to the healthy milk from the English countryside.
Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies are trying to find new ways to attract customers. One new idea is to make chocolate bars into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts for people who want something different.
However, cacao farmers still face problems because cocoa bean prices fell in the late 1980s. Many small cacao farmers had to close their businesses. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and is very good at making art. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. 
As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring at all. He is very interesting and his art is beautiful. He shows me some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them." Peter never planned to sell his art. About five years ago, some friends told him he should have an exhibition so more people could see his work. They helped him talk to a gallery owner in London. At his first exhibition, 70% of his pieces were sold.
His second exhibition opened yesterday. The prices for his art are very high, around £2,000 for some decorations. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he does not set the prices, but he knows his work is special. The gallery owner told him that one day, when he stops making art, everyone will want his pieces.
Peter wishes he had started making art earlier in his life. He thinks he could have made even more wonderful things. Now, he feels he cannot do as much because he is older. However, his work is very different from the simple shell crafts you find in seaside shops. He has a creative mind and makes boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of very realistic flowers.
Peter has his own way of working. He uses materials he finds, like cardboard from shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens." His work is very detailed and beautiful.
Peter travels to many places to find tiny shells. He has been to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He lies on the beach to look for beautiful shells. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures inside. He explains that many people walk on the beach and break shells, and the sea also breaks them. He believes it is okay to collect shells that are no longer homes for animals.
Peter's argument about collecting shells is strong. He creates beautiful art from the shells he finds, and his work is often more beautiful than the shells themselves.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model and often travels to nice places for work. When she is not modeling, she studies for her school exams. 
One day, a reporter named Jane Laidlaw is waiting to meet Kira. The receptionist at the modeling agency tells Jane that Kira will be late. Jane worries about this. She thinks about all the bad things she has heard about models, like they can be difficult or vain. She wonders if Kira will come at all.
When Kira arrives, she is smiling and relaxed. She is with her mother. Kira is not wearing fancy clothes; she has on a simple black dress and trainers. She is very friendly and tall. Kira explains that models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work. Her mother is proud of her.
Kira became a model by chance. Her older sister suggested she enter a modeling competition. Kira did not want to, but her sister sent in some photos. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. This made her feel confident, and she won the competition easily. After that, a modeling agency in London offered her work.
Kira has to balance her life as a student and a model. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard, but she believes she is still the same person. She says, "I have become more confident, but I can still stand up for myself."
Being a model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job. Kira cannot always make plans with her friends because she does not know her schedule. However, her friends understand and do not complain.
Kira has a bright future ahead of her. She is talented and has support from her family and friends. When Jane asks Kira what she would like to do if she were not a model, Kira thinks for a moment and says, "I would like to do what you are doing."

Father and son start Gold Rush
Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in Wales, they believe they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding a lot of gold; now we just need to dig a little more to find it all."
The father and son have spent their lives looking for gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth. They chose the best area to study. After clearing the land and finding some gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission to work, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.
Now, they do not have enough money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a little deeper where the gold is. Chris says, "Right now, it looks doubtful, but we have some people to contact."
Last week, news about their dig spread in the valleys, and many people became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, the manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, it could bring more people here, but I hope many people do not come and damage the hillside."
The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. Now, individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. He said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It is exciting to find hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. 
When she is not teaching, Rachel goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. Rachel dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. 
A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. Rachel says, "No one has tested it yet, but I don’t think it would be a nice trip."
Rachel remembers her first dive. She got into the vehicle on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would feel in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, they found many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. 
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can do my research on the 'black smokers'." Black smokers are underwater volcanoes that release hot water that looks like black smoke. This water comes out at one metre per second and is 350 degrees hot.
Rachel felt scared the first time she dived with an American team. They were using a 50-metre rope when there was an explosion. There was a loud bang, and she thought, "I’m going to die." They waited in silence. When nothing happened, they were very relieved. 
Rachel loves diving to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She thinks, "I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen this before." She studied black smokers for three years for her PhD. When she saw them for real, it was an incredible feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired. My mind was confused with foreign train times, money, and languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. 
I just had to buy one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five years old, I could travel for a whole month anywhere in Europe. After sleeping in a train corridor, normal beds feel different. Carrying all my things in a backpack made me travel simply. I learned to throw away things I didn’t need, like old socks and finished books. This way of traveling is part of the Inter-Rail spirit. With a ticket in my hand, I felt free. 
On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t know how special this train ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra miles didn’t cost us anything. We were not only interested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and only saw the most popular sights. 
I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We just wanted to enjoy ourselves. We were like other Inter-Rail travelers, sharing space, food, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place you only knew by name. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. 
To really understand Europe, you need to see it yourself. Everyone knows about it, but it is different when you experience it. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps people see this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away.

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage is missing can be very disappointing. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a different place with a different weather and have to wear clothes that are not right for that place.
Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes, and it is hard for any airline to promise that your checked luggage will travel with you, especially if you have to change planes.
Here is how it works: Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for the bags to be checked and loaded onto the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change from one flight to another. This time is often longer to help with moving bags. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights. This can cause issues with the baggage system. Human mistakes can also happen, like if a label on a bag gets lost.
Big airports, called 'hubs', can have more problems because they handle many bags. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways had two million passengers changing planes at Heathrow, mostly between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4.
Even busy airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. Some airports have a higher chance of losing bags when passengers change planes. Miami airport in the United States is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights in Latin America.
To avoid losing your luggage, try to book direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight. Make sure to label your luggage with your home and holiday addresses, and include your flight numbers.
If your luggage is still missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before you leave the airport.

The Kingfisher**
Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees grow over the stream, giving some shade to the shallow water. The main colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and looks like a flash of light. It is gone in a second, but you remember it because it is so special.
Charlie James loved kingfishers when he was young. He feels very strongly about this little bird, but he cannot say exactly why. There are many stories about kingfishers.
