I carefully lifted the snake and walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to let the snake go. I pointed it towards a tree. When I let go of the snake's head, it surprised me by climbing up onto my shoulders like a warm scarf. 
My four children and I stood together with the snake. My oldest child, DJ, said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not." I asked the children to help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, the snake went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake left our yard, my three-year-old son, Clay, said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

'Write to Me!'**
In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming less common. But for me, getting a letter is special. There is excitement when it arrives, joy in seeing who sent it, and happiness in reading it. Writing letters has been part of my life for a long time. I started by writing little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.
When I was 18, I moved to London to study to be a doctor. I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote to me, and I loved his funny letters. Most letters from home talked about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we wrote to each other. Writing letters helped our relationships. I found it easier to say what I felt in writing than by talking. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it is even better to get a lot of news in a letter! I especially like letters with beautiful stamps from other countries.
I get letters from my friend Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. I also have a friend in France. We started writing after talking in a restaurant on holiday. If I had not asked for her address, I would not have been able to write to her. Now we write regularly. I can practice my French with her because she does not speak English. We have visited each other’s homes.
This summer, my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that we wrote for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about us!
I am happy that my children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, set up by my penfriend. I encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into rocks in France are being damaged. There are about 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps. Scientists are worried that these drawings will not last for future generations. The mountain has drawings that are 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. 
More and more tourists are visiting the site, but some are ruining the pictures by writing on them. Jean Clottes, who is the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think these pictures will always be here. But if the damage continues, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and damaging them. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. 
When tourists cannot take a good photo, they rub the drawings to make them clearer. The weather makes the drawings smooth, but when the sun shines, some people rub them to see them better. Some visitors bring sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.
Experts have different ideas about how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way to save the site is to make it a "no-go" area. This means only guided tours would be allowed. He believes that if we do not protect the site, it will be destroyed, and important research will stop. 
Clottes disagrees. He thinks that closing the site will upset local people. The site was made a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we should try to save it. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea is not the best. We want people to see the site, but it is hard to stop damage because the area is very big. We may need to charge a fee to help pay for guards."
Annie Echassoux, who has studied the site, is worried that it is now easier for tourists to visit. They can avoid a long walk by using vehicles. She believes the best solution is to block off the area and have guides. "We need money to protect this historic site," she says. "If we do not act, we will lose the drawings for the next generation."

Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for some parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not a new sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t buy everything, and when I say yes, I feel bad for buying unhealthy food. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices. I can’t win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This advertising makes children want things, and they often do not understand why their parents say no. Parents often talk about how bad sugar is for teeth, but children do not listen when they see fun ads on TV.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel they have to compete with ads and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow ads to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Susan Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks to her children about food and ads. She feels better because her son now thinks most ads are not good. They do not argue much in the supermarket because the children do not ask for things she does not want to buy.
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am happy, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help parents by moving sweets away from the checkout areas or by having play areas for children. Even if parents spend less money without their children, shopping without their children’s demands would likely bring in more customers.

Climbing Walls**
Climbers used to go to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is excited. High on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall.
Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.
Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls with special bricks. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He created a wall with natural rock in concrete. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had problems. These walls were only straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material that looked like the shapes on cliffs. This material could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could build overhanging walls easily. This new system gave climbers many different holds to use.

'So You Want to Be an Actor'**
Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone this, they might say it is a risky job. Acting can be risky because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy, but others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. It is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own dreams.
There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take written tests, and there is no guarantee that you will get a job after your training. Success depends on luck and talent. There is a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.
Many people want to know what talent is. Talent is a natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person's courage and belief in what they do. 
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important thing is the moment when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to perform.
If you ask actors how they succeed, they may not know. They understand some things about their skills and the skills of others, but they do not take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their last job, and fame can be short. 
Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been without work, selling clothes or serving food. Then, you may get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often do not talk about their chances. They find ways to deal with the stress of trying for a role and the fear of being rejected. No one likes to be rejected. 
From the first moment you start trying for acting jobs, you are saying you are ready and hopefully talented enough. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care enough, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.
A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places in the world. She loves exciting food and knows what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a must-have for modern cooks. It gives simple and expert advice on cooking, with many great recipes that are not boring. It has been updated and is the best book to answer the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?"
B. Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in just 15 years. He is the owner of a well-known French restaurant in Britain. Now, he has a book to go with his first TV show called "Blanc Mange." Raymond wants to help everyone cook better by showing how and why ingredients work together. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. His book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical book that explains why some dishes can go wrong and teaches some basic food science. Monsieur Blanc loves to cook for others, and this book shows he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that means the best in French cooking. For 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students to be great cooks. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have released a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which has 100 of the school's best recipes. The recipes are all classic but still feel fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also changed to make dishes healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then has sections for Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have shared their famous recipes and secrets in this book.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, does not agree. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes you can make tasty food in the same time it takes to get a pizza. He has already written two successful books about this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and friendly way, with over 200 recipes from around the world. Just because he likes fast food does not mean he does not love good food. If you think fast food cannot be great, try his recipes: they are delicious!

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. Matt thought the city was fun at first, but later it became boring. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he lost it suddenly. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. He met the head chef of a local hotel, which is one of the best in the country. By selling meat to the hotel, more people learned about his farm. Now, he also sells meat online. Matt is happy to be out of the office, but he still works long hours, like before.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Ron told the counselor that he did not want to go back to his old job. This surprised the counselor because most people want to find work quickly. Ron and his wife got married young, and their children are grown up, so they did not need to worry about money. They moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends, but they still keep in touch, and many friends visit them.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but she worked very long hours. Katherine did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left. Many people thought she would get bored, but she has not. She has deadlines for her fashion business, which keeps her busy. Katherine feels happier and less stressed now. However, she misses talking to her colleagues. She loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault. When she worked for a company, she cared, but now she cares even more because her name is on the products.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance when he was 22 years old. He liked the excitement of the job, but he did not find it rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he decided to leave and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. Paul knew he needed training to change careers, so he took courses in massage. Then, he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets about his choice. He feels more in control of his life now and is very happy.

'A Winning Game'**
Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse are two brothers in their forties. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game called pichenotte. This game is special to them because their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought it from Quebec, Canada. He taught the game to the family. Every weekend and holiday, the family played pichenotte and had a great time.
When the family moved to New Mexico, they still played the game. Their grandfather made the pichenotte board from old wooden crates. Visitors were often curious because no one knew the game in southern USA. Three years ago, Dave saw that their old board was damaged, so he made a new one. A relative saw it and wanted one, and then a friend wanted one too.
One night, the brothers took a new board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. People were surprised and said, "I won’t play that silly game." But soon, they sat down to play and enjoyed it! When people asked about the game’s history, Dave did some research. He found that the game probably started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game changed into 'squails' in Britain, and British people brought it to Canada. The name pichenotte comes from the French-Canadian version of the game in Quebec.
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces called 'pucks'. They flick the pucks across a round board using their fingers. If a puck goes into a small hole, it is worth 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. The game has eight small posts that make it harder to play. A game usually lasts about two minutes.
When the brothers saw how much people liked the game at the bar, they made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people came to buy them, and the game became popular. They even started having championships and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. As more people learned about the game, the brothers sold boards quickly. They decided to make pichenotte boards full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made more than 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. Norm says, "They are very strong and last a long time."
The boards cost $595 each and can be bought from the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game yet. But the brothers hope that one day they will have a nice car instead of a workshop full of wood. For now, they are happy to play the game they love.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first come to the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a flat piece of land covered with weeds. For a long time, people thought this land was useless. One man, with the help of his wife, worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful place you see today. 
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the lovely landscape you see now. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was also done by hand. After the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. 
In the Model Village, hundreds of trees and bushes were planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they needed to survive near the sea and in strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from Canada and New Zealand. 
The whole village was created by Colin Sims. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, wood, and plastic so they can last in all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how to use these materials, but soon he became an expert himself. 
You will see that all the models are made to the same scale and have many small details. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality and care. The methods used here have been used in other model villages in England and even in some college courses about modeling. 
All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House. This is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, similar to manor houses in the West Country. 
As you walk around the village, you will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition. Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; if you slip, it can take us a long time to fix them. You can take photos from the paths only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead. 
To make your visit more fun, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations. We are always updating the models and need to know which ones need work. 
We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don’t forget to tell your friends about it!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers print pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules that newspaper editors should follow. Sometimes, pop stars take pictures with paparazzi, but this is not common. Most of the time, it hurts people in the public eye when they see their private moments on the front page. Very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to help with these problems. These pictures are rarely important for the public. For example, do private pictures of pop stars help solve a crime? How does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-distance pictures before. Since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. 
The PCC should look into the recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action against these bad stories? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers would report this, and it would be on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected and might not be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore.
If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it talk to the person affected and encourage them to complain? If the person does not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Celebrities and royals might expect the PCC to take action, but they could be upset if it does not. The job is too big for the PCC. How could it watch all the British press: national, local, and magazines? There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone’s privacy is invaded, would they want to go through an investigation? Most people probably just want to forget about it and move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they do not want to become public if they complain. In this way, the PCC could also become a problem.
One British comedian had trouble with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, and he did not complain later when a photographer took pictures of him and his family on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would use the pictures again and say he was angry, thinking it was just a joke. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.
**Questions:**
1. What do British tabloid newspapers often print?
2. What is the Press Complaints Commission (PCC)?
3. Why did the actress have a good reason to complain?
4. What might happen if the PCC takes action against newspapers?
5. Why did the comedian not complain about the pictures taken of him?

Many college students get advice when they finish school and look for their first job. This article talks about finding a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one. We also do not talk about people who leave a job they do not like after a few weeks. Instead, we will help those who want to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and know what you want to do.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to focus on a specific area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, you should be careful when picking your second job. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, this job should help you grow and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are ready to work.
Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because the people were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance to move up in that job. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have learned a lot and my job has grown." From the start, her boss wanted to help her develop. Her job title is the same, but her tasks have changed. She now does most of the letters and budgets. She also answers questions from important people and those who want to start their own business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her special projects and events to organize.

'Confident People: What’s Their Secret?'**
Confident people seem to be born that way, but many say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter’s school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very scared, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, I don’t feel guilty if I leave some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to calm down.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am confident, but I often feel scared. I learned to look confident because it is important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel tense in important situations. My mother gave me good advice when I worried about my clothes: “Who is looking at you? Everyone is busy worrying about themselves.” I believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt more confident.
**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work. I have built my confidence over the years. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will be more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don’t let that bother me. You must like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses, which help me feel better about myself. It is good to set small goals and see what you achieve.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary. I sat in meetings and was scared to speak. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my ideas. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day.” I also wrote down some notes to help me. I think everyone feels a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

A Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional. If the line breaks, finders keep it. I have many more kites." He showed me a pile of beautiful kites at his feet. All the kites were 120 cm wide and long, made of paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. 
In the middle of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A row of competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys were in the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person had four different kites to show. The kites were judged on how they looked, how stable they were in the air, and how well they flew. 
"Flying kites is not hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Come to my house, and I will show you how to make a kite." I got five invitations that day, and I decided to go to his house. There, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers in a big room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help him fix his kite, but I could not. Instead, I drove to the southern part of the state, heading towards Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with thick rainforests. 
I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started walking, I should have known that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I met Baba, who took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. 
At night, it was very dark, and I heard many sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby, and many creatures were moving around. In the morning, I saw a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, there was wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got very wet. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, muddy, at the bottom of the hill. 
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" They were very friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of the people.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
"I love shopping! I can't stop spending money! When I have money, I go shopping. I can't walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we go shopping together a lot. We are both addicted to shopping!"
B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my son and daughter shopping for clothes, but I don’t enjoy it because we all like different things. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less money than I really did."
C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
"I only shop for things I need. I don’t like shopping and only go when I have to. When I go, I know what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather do something else."
D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want. I don’t waste time and I try to shop quickly. I do have some clothes I bought that I don’t wear, so maybe I make mistakes when I shop."
E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
"I really don’t like shopping. I hate shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want. The shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. I go food shopping once a week and do it quickly."
F. Lisa, 22, actress  
"I think I am a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often buy things. I don’t usually go with a plan, but if I see something I like, I buy it."
G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant  
"I am a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and I don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I feel worse because I spent too much money."
H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it is too busy. I am a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want, and I look in different shops to find the best price. It takes me a long time!"
I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager  
"I don’t like shopping. I work in the city, so shopping is not fun for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try on clothes because it is too much work. Sometimes the clothes I buy don’t fit, but I don’t care too much. I would rather make mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping." 
**Questions:**
1. What does Melanie think about shopping?
2. Who does Brenda say does most of the food shopping?
3. What does Juliet only shop for?
4. How does Lizzie feel about shopping for clothes?
5. What does Lisa do when she goes shopping with her friends?
6. Why does Suki sometimes feel worse after shopping?
7. What day does Ann-Marie not like to shop?
8. Why does Linda not try on clothes when she shops?

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, children can join a quiz about surprises. You can get free quiz sheets at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will find 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz sheets are available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.
**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is normal for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has bought works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The Gallery is happy to say that the restaurant has improved and expanded. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers many hot and cold dishes at good prices.

Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and the collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Little Chefs**
A group of children aged ten to fifteen spend their Saturdays learning to cook. Many children want to join, so there is a waiting list of 30 kids. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food.
Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together."
Flora is twelve years old. She has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby instead of staying home on weekends. At first, I didn't want to come, but now I am very happy I did."
Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, but the kitchen can be messy when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, they will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**STAMP COLLECTING - A FUN HOBBY**

Starting your collection is easy because you can find stamps everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends. 
When you want to collect stamps seriously, you can join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps. You can receive these stamps in three ways: 
1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful pack with interesting facts.
3. We can send you individual stamps for you to put in your own special book.
The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join for just £5 for two years. If you join with friends, you can get a discount. This is a good deal! 
When you join, you will get a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also receive a 4-page guide with tips on how to collect stamps and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Why not start this fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection and searching for new ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and have fun collecting stamps! To join, fill out the application form and send your membership fee. You will get your Starter Pack within 28 days.

**MONEY**
What is money? Money is things like the pound, the dollar, or the franc. They are like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that does not cost much to make.
A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, traded the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people who wanted what the other had. Over time, many societies made their own types of money, called 'currencies', so people could trade more easily. Different currencies started to work together, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

Write a Winning Story!**
You can win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other people will win £100. We need people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a television reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories.
Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like. Here are some tips to help you:
1. **Write about what you know**: This is important for every writer. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and problems with friends. Try to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read more.
2. **Get your facts right**: If you describe a town or explain something, make sure it is correct. Don’t write about things you are not sure about.
3. **Hold the reader's attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A bad ending is not good.
4. **Think about the characters**: Make the people in your story feel real by using good words.
Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and on one side of the paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions.
You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not be printed or recorded anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. 
The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**
Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she got a good education. This was not common because most women did not have many chances to study.
After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important works about math. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created some scientific tools to help her work.
At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people who studied it were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**
**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long. It goes through Nene Park, starting in Peterborough and ending at Wansford, which is next to the A1 main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers to Yarwell, the western end of the line.  
**Fares:**  
- Adult: £10.00  
- Child: £5.00  
- Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00  
Special prices may be available on public holidays.
**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It is a great place for a family day out. There are many areas for picnics, boating lakes, and a nature reserve. There is also a miniature railway.
**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a special collection of historic trains from Europe. You can see famous trains like the De Glen Compound from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these trains all year, but the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

Nene Valley Railway is popular with film makers because it can look like a railway in any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed!

From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can bring students to visit the railway and do projects. There is an educational pack for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. You need to book one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.
**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a great place for family events or company visits. It can help you plan a fun afternoon or evening. You can arrange food, drinks, and entertainment. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass**
Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 types of grass, and they grow in every part of the earth. Grass can live in very cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. 
Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass to live. 
Grass grows back very quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass grows from below the soil, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food for them.

**Text:**
Kal Kaur Rai is a young woman who loves fashion. She just won the title of Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked to draw clothes and make designs. She did not tell her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to work in fashion. She thought they wanted her to have a different job, so she went to university to study management.
After university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She went to many events but could not buy the designer clothes she wanted. So, she started to make skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. 
Kal found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs. The clothes were very popular, and none of them came back. This made her feel good, and she decided to leave her advertising job. She took a loan of £20,000 to start her own women’s clothing brand. 
Kal's parents were happy for her and said they would support her. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than £500,000. Her designs are in fashion magazines, and she makes clothes for pop stars. She feels very lucky to have won this award. She says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**
The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given good service to many people from all over the world. Over 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here in the last 80 years. 
The hotel is on a main road to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to get to the center of town. Buses to other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should not take buses with a blue sign that says "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.
The hotel has 200 comfortable single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the hall. The hotel also has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking for cars in the hotel area. Guests can get daily newspapers for free and buy stamps at the office.
Guests who stay for a long time must pay for their room every week in advance. They need to tell the hotel one week before they leave. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.
Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. If guests are studying or working late, they can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing their name on a list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 choices for breakfast and dinner.
No animals or fires are allowed in the hotel. Guests should be quiet, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If guests arrive by train, it is better to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main train station.

Tom Cruise**
Tom Cruise is a very successful actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked to be in school plays.
After high school, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. 
Ten years later, Tom became very famous. He was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood and earned a lot of money for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and has many fans all over the world.

'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? 
Bo the cat wanted to explore a furniture van. She had a big adventure! The driver found her after he drove for more than 500 kilometres. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. The driver gave Bo some milk and tried to find her owner. He called his last customers, but they did not lose a cat. 
It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was also looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that delivered to a neighbour. He remembered the name of the company. He called them, and soon Bo was back home safely.'

The Ghan Train**
Mark Ottaway took a train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cooler south. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late.
In the 1920s, there was a plan to connect Darwin and Adelaide by train. A train line was built from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but it often had problems with flooding. A new train line was finished a few months before Mark's trip. The train can go fast, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday.
The Ghan was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia by train would save time and money. The Ghan is the first train in the world to go north to south across a continent.
When Mark waited to get on the Ghan, he saw that everyone was excited for the trip. Many older Australians were especially happy. The first stop was Katherine, where the train stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip. Mark stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where he went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so they just walked around it and watched the sunset.
From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. But on the third day, they reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. Mark's journey was over. The train may not have done everything the ads promised, but it took him to some amazing places in Australia.

Climbing Ben Nevis**
Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is the highest mountain in Britain, and it can be very cold there. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first climb on Ben Nevis.
It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We climbed up the north side of the mountain to a place called Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters high, which is a long climb. We planned to camp for three days in the "Carries," which are big bowls in the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be very hard, like ice.
Even though some people in my group were very experienced, we took safety equipment. This included lights to get help, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started climbing. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always hard.
The path went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest climber, so I had to rest more often. The others stopped to let me catch up, but when I did, they started climbing again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb.
After climbing 200 meters, we reached Tower Ridge. It is only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops down very far on both sides. We had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. But we were not lucky; a mist came down.
Getting back down to camp can be as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn can lead to dangerous places in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I enjoyed the climb when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top!

Anna's New School**
This week is very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a great place. The builders used wood to make it, like our old school, but this school is also good for the environment. It took many months to build, and we watched it being built. It was exciting to see the builders working, but it also meant some nice land was gone. The building was noisy, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms, much bigger than the old school next door. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use them when our new sports field is ready.
When you enter the school, you will see that there are no heaters! The heat comes from the people inside, like the children, teachers, and computers. The building keeps the heat and sound inside, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like a concert hall!
You will also notice that there is a tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that we can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.
Even though we are using the school now, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

No Title**
A month ago, I did not know that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place was not very nice, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.
On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we were not sure how.
Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock climbing. Then we changed activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**
On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. In my handbag were my cheque book, address book, and my purse. My purse had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I lost my handbag, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the road and cried.
A young man asked me what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely. Soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the bus company. He said they had my handbag and would bring it back to me. 
I got my handbag back, and everything was inside and safe. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I appreciate their kindness and honesty.
Mrs. B. James, Newport

Sharks**
Sharks are some of the most scary animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food in the water because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.
Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they do not sleep much. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting animals.
