'Joining the Kirov Ballet
My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak in Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could understand each other.
Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mom stayed with me. When she left, I felt a little sad. I even called her late at night because I felt lonely.
The ballet classes in Russia are harder than in England. I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This helps me do well in class. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends.
Now that I feel settled, I feel at home here. I like to walk around the city and visit different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was warm for that time of year! My room is warm and cozy.
Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**
For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, and they enjoyed the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people decided that the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. 
In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, on the frozen Torne River. This building was called Arctic Hall, and it attracted many visitors. One night, some guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel started.
Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous around the world. When winter starts, a team of builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As they finish one part, it opens for visitors and guests, while they continue to build other parts. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. 
The ICEHOTEL is built outside, using snow and ice, so the finishing date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, even if it is very cold outside. Guests receive warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea to bring sweaters, scarves, and warm socks. Guests should wear shoes that are a bit bigger than normal to fit thick socks.
If you want to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes and other items on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these things when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you arrive.
The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but it is only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Shopping for Furniture**
A report by Dave Worthington
Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday. Many people, up to 6,000, came to the shop. There were special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). 
The shop's normal hours are from 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. 
A police officer said: "We knew a lot of people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait in line. 
There was also a long line of cars trying to park. Many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.
One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: "I waited in line for three hours, but I did not have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. It was not safe, so I will come back when they reopen, but I do not want to wait in line again."

Membership**
The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is one of the most active arts groups in Britain.
**Society Magazines**
We make several magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine has short stories by famous British writers and gives new writers a chance to print their work. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can see articles from recent issues on our website.
**National Short Story Competition**
We have the National Short Story Competition, which is the biggest competition for short stories. Anyone aged 18 and over can enter. Stories can be about any topic and should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay to enter, but non-members pay £5. The competition is open from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's annual book. The winner will get a contract to publish their own book of short stories.
**Education**
For almost thirty years, the Society has worked with schools to help children and teachers with writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998. It is for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.
**The Writers' Cafe**
The Writers' Cafe is a social place for the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, with vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm from Monday to Friday, and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.
**Becoming a Member**
We have members all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or older can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Free-diving in the Caribbean**
Tanya Streeter is a famous free-diver. She has four world records in free-diving. This sport is about diving deep into the ocean while holding your breath. In 2003, Tanya became the first person to dive 120 meters deep without help. She held her breath for more than three and a half minutes. This made her the first woman to break a world record that was held by a man.
A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents, but Tanya believes safety is very important. She also thinks training is important. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya has a regular training schedule. 
She spends two-thirds of her training in the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she does not want to hurt her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. 
When she practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She tries to do fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important for her to not get tired, or it can affect her training.
When Tanya is not training, she often appears in public to promote sports products. She also helps environmental groups by doing research or making films. Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved swimming and exploring the sea life in rock pools. She says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. 
Because she is famous in some countries, people listen to her when she talks about the environment. Tanya is in her thirties now, and she wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five, so she does not plan to stop for many years.

**CARTOON FILMS**
Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons exciting for people of all ages. 
In the late 1970s, many people thought cartoons were only for children. But then, some directors had new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. 
However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, *The Black Cauldron* did not do well. It was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role**
Caroline Benson is a new TV star. She talks about her first role on TV. "I never thought I would spend my first year at university making a TV show called The Finnegans. I only acted in school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven years old. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I always wanted to play her.
I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me. She said they wanted to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director and asked him to meet me. I flew back and got the role.
Filming started a week after university began, so I asked for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to write the essays I missed. I didn’t tell my friends at university, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel very lucky.
After university, I want to be an actor. My family is not in acting, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I have not received any offers yet. I don’t know how I did it all because I also had a busy social life. When filming finished, I didn’t know what to do. I have acted in two college plays since then. Unfortunately, I have not been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I am going to Greece for the summer with friends."

'No Title
I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976. My goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a big company that is growing all over the world. Since we started, I have learned a lot. I want to share what I have learned in this book. I believe we have important ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our beliefs.
This is not a normal business book, and it is not just about my life. The main idea is that to be successful in business, you need to be different. Business can be fun, and it can be run with love. It can also help people. In business, like in life, I want to enjoy what I do, feel like I am part of a family, and be excited by new things. I want the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way.
Now, this book shares my ideas with everyone. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can do. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.'

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**
Jules Verne runs a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can carry 160 guests in double cabins. All cabins have outside views and a private shower and toilet. On the ship, there is air-conditioning, a sun-deck, a lounge, a bar, a dining room, a shop, and a library.
**Itinerary**
**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and arrive in Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.
**Day 2:** After seeing Oporto in the morning, you will return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.
**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, where port wine is made. At dinner, you can try the tasty food and drink from this area.
**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will go by bus to the old town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum used to be a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Then, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.
**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. If the river is deep enough, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach and see many interesting things along the way.
**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro river valley train for a beautiful ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.
**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, you will travel down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on the Lady Ivy May.
**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

HONEY**
Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel very far, up to seventy-five thousand kilometers, and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. 
In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey a lot and used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that honey can help reduce tiredness and improve sports performance. Honey is not just food; it can also help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich**
Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a part of Britain. It has been a place to live for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. When the Normans came in 1066, it was one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a popular place for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and celebrated its 900th birthday recently. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it became a city and could govern itself.
Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It grew for 300 years and became rich. It was famous for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many students and is a busy place for business, especially for insurance services.
Norwich has many fun things to do, like theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centres. There is also a football team called 'The Canaries', which wears green and yellow. No one knows why they are called that. 
One new attraction is a shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, there was a big hole in the city while builders worked on it. They moved a lot of earth to make a park on the roof of the Mall, with water pools and many trees. The people of Norwich are happy that the old open market is still there, next to the new shopping centre. Both places are busy, showing that Norwich has a good mix of old and new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**
Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, becomes very colorful. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, which happens every year for nine days. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a car park in Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries are expected to come.
**What to See**
The pilots talk to each other using radios. They light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great time to take photos. You should arrive just after night falls or before 5:30 am to see these "glows" as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons are in many sizes and colors, some look like animals or cartoon characters, and some are shaped like popular drinks and fast food. Kids will enjoy it.
In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies that offer this. Another option is to take a cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere, and you can see the festival from above.
There are many other fun things for visitors of all ages, like balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.
**The Albuquerque Box**
This is a special wind pattern that helps balloon pilots. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This means that skilled pilots can control where their balloons go by going up or down.
**Practical Advice**
Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid a long wait. Wear several layers of thin clothes because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, bring your camera. If you do not have a digital camera, you will need high-speed film for evening and night photos.

The Eden Project**
The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is a very popular place for tourists. The big 'biospheres' look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. They show how important plants are for people. 
Many things we use every day come from plants. For example, we get wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate from plants. There are over 135,000 types of plants grown at the Eden Project. 
Even if it is cold outside, electric heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. There is also a zone that looks like the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. Soon, they will build a desert zone too.

No Title**
Some people have said they do not like this year's book, New Writing 3. I do not understand why. It has 500 pages of good writing for £6.99, which is great! Most of the book is fiction, with parts of novels and short stories. There are nice pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. 
It is interesting that many less-known writers wrote about food. For example, Jane Harris's story, Those Nails, should not be read after eating. It has some very unpleasant scenes! 
There are also poems from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You can find parts of novels that are not finished by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a little non-fiction. This includes a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers and a surprising piece by Ursula Owen about herself. 
This is a great collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will be like!

**Text:**
"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violin teacher. "It's a time when you learn about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some five-year-olds who really want to learn.
When she started teaching in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts one hour, every two weeks. Also, each student has one private lesson with her every week. Parents must come to the classes too. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons.
From the first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have played for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how they play and how they read music. Margaret says her method is not meant to make great violinists. She suggests that students who do very well should leave and learn the violin in a more traditional way.

Moonshine**
The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. The CD is called "Here Again" and it comes after their last CD, "The Waves." There are some changes in the band. Tom Wilcott is now playing the bass guitar. He replaced Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined the band as the drummer.
The first song on the CD is a dance song. This shows that the band is not going to focus only on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance song and is even louder. Most of the other songs are in the band’s usual slow style. These two dance songs may surprise many fans. They could become popular hits because they are very good. 
The singer, Rob Letchford, shows how talented he is by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be happy that he recorded these songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. But fans who bought tickets do not need to worry. All the concerts will be rescheduled when Rob gets better.
On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from slow songs to dance songs that make you want to move. However, I think they put their best songs at the beginning, and the last few songs are not as good. Still, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and will bring more success to the band.

San Francisco**
San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to see this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Even though San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbour, it was found by land, not by sea.
In 1849, many people came to San Francisco to find gold. But the people who became rich were not the gold miners. The richest people owned banks and law firms, and they built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill.
Today, many tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Some people even take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

SAMUEL PEPYS**
The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It talks about everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important news, like sickness, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his mistakes - he often slept in church or looked at pretty girls. He describes his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up, and he worries about her being sick. 
Pepys liked books, music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. He was a busy man with many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**
A long time ago, people did not think about shoes being comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins. People tied these skins around their ankles when it was cold. Today, we still use leather for shoes, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton, depending on what is popular.
About one hundred and fifty years ago, people started to wear different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. In the past, all shoes were made by hand. Now, many shoes are made by machines in big factories. The use of sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many shoes quickly and at lower prices for more people.

No Title**
When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women enjoy running and feel good about it. So, I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because many race organizers say there are not enough women in running, but they do not make separate changing rooms for them.
I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. Many of them wanted to lose weight, but I think they had not thought about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined it was hard and painful. They did not think about having fun, talking, and smiling while running in nice places, like by a river.
At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes! They also learned about healthy eating and staying fit. I wanted to help women with running, and I feel very happy to see how much they have improved. They are happy too!

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**
In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people came to Alaska to find gold and get rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means "far, distant place." In 1909, Iditarod became the largest city in Alaska for a short time.
In summer, boats brought supplies to the towns. But in winter, rivers and the ocean froze, and it was hard to reach the towns. So, in 1910, a winter path was made for dog teams pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to travel across Alaska. They stopped at "roadhouses" to sleep and eat.
The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced boats and dog teams for transport. However, in 1925, dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The medicine to cure the disease was in Anchorage, far away. Airplanes were new, and no one knew if they could fly in the cold. The best pilot was away, so they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine.
The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly on the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty dog teams just six days to finish the journey. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian looking for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers with his dog Togo, who was a great guide in the snow. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, stopped the team from falling into icy water. The medicine arrived, and Balto became a hero.
Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the famous route from 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth."

Sweden's Ice Hotel**
The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland. In winter, the temperature can be very low, around -40 degrees Celsius. Every year, 6,000 visitors come to see a very special hotel. This hotel is made of ice. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in ice rooms. You can even have a wedding there!
The bar is also made of ice, so it is not good to put hot drinks on it. The bedrooms are about -4 degrees Celsius, but guests get special sleeping bags to keep warm. If you need warm clothes, the hotel can give them to you.
The hotel is always new because it melts in summer. Each winter, workers rebuild it. It takes 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow to make the hotel.

Maria Mutola**
In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl on a boys' football team in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the other team complained." The story was in a local newspaper. Jose Craveirinha, who helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He saw that she was very fast.
Jose talked to Maria about athletics. She did not understand at first because she only knew about football. Then he bought her running shoes and took her to train. It was hard work, and her legs hurt a lot. Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful and help their family. They agreed to let him take her to train.
In 1991, Maria accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but I worried about my parents having enough food. They worried about dresses and make-up. They did not know much about me or my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were great, and I learned a lot."
Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**
The Grand Canyon is in the United States. It was made by the Colorado River. Many people visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and see the view. The view is very beautiful, and it is even better because of the Skywalk. 
The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass, so you can see the lovely rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. The Skywalk opened in 2007, and many people have visited it since then. 
When you walk on the Skywalk, you must wear special covers on your shoes to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air, like a bird.

**THE ROCKIES**
The Rocky Mountains are a big mountain range in North America. They start in the North-west and go down to the south. The Rockies are not as high as the Alps, but they are still very beautiful. 
There are many roads to drive through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You can start your journey in Vancouver, which is one of the most beautiful cities in Canada. In Vancouver, you can enjoy the water and the mountains. You can even ski just 15 minutes by car from the city.
Before, there were thirty trains every day from Vancouver to other places. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still very exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will see the best views at night.

ZOOS**
People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. A long time ago, the rulers of China opened a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In early zoos, animals did tricks for visitors. Now, this does not happen. Today, the purpose of zoos is for people to see animals acting naturally.
Most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. Some people think zoos are good. They say zoos help us learn about nature and see wild animals up close. These things would not be possible without zoos.
However, some people do not like zoos. They believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and do not get good food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  
I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, and other bands wore bright T-shirts. We did not look like professional adult bands, but we were good at playing because we practiced a lot. It was exciting to watch the performances, especially when my band played on stage!  
My school has a great jazz band, but not everyone can join. Only about half of the students who want to play get accepted. However, anyone who wants to play can go to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  
Many adults are surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it is because pop music is not challenging enough for serious music students like me. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old. You can create your own music, but you also feel part of its history, like the great jazz performers before you. My school is lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we would not be able to improve our music!

Watering the Desert**
In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain from November to March. It does not rain often, but when it does, the water pipes in the city cannot handle it. This makes the streets very wet, like rivers. Many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the people are happy.
Marrakesh has parks and gardens, not because of the rain, but because of underground channels. These channels were made in the 11th century and bring water from the mountains all year. Places that are mostly dry and get water this way are called oases.
If you travel south from Marrakesh, you will reach Skoura. In Skoura, people use all the land they can to grow food. There are small squares made by the water channels. The Atlas mountains, which have snow in winter, look beautiful in the background.

Gareth Ellis**
Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has two older brothers who work in banking and computers. But Gareth wants to be a clown. 
Three years ago, Gareth and his parents joined a circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since he was three years old." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath looked for jobs in the circus. They both found jobs, and Gareth started to train to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. 
In the summer, they travel with the circus and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers can take care of the house while they are away. Kath says, "It was not easy. We had to think about many things. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."
Gareth talks about his education. He says, "People ask about my school, but wherever we go, someone teaches me. I use the same books as my friends at school, and I have a computer. I have not fallen behind." 
About the future, Kath says, "It was a hard choice, but this is the best way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I am happy, and we enjoy it." Gareth adds, "I want to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**
Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people. The members are aged 8 to 18 years old. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.
We have three centers in the country where young people can meet and work on projects. We want to open more centers in other places. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. 
Sophie was one of them. She says: "I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was amazed by what they could do. Age didn't matter; they could do stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought I could. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19, and now I am the youngest worker on a big news website, checking articles before they go online."
**Get Involved at Every Level**
When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to help each other. 'Peer trainers' are members who are 12 years old and older. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. Some members also present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff.
Eight-eighteen News has training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know wants to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**
Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.
During the short summer in Antarctica, we take tourists on a big plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. The flight dates for next year are not set yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be changed if we need to change the date.
**Questions**
Here are answers to common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.
**How long is the flight?**  
The flight is about 12 hours. After about four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica and the rest of the time flying back home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will talk about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that shows you what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.
**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers get two boarding passes. At the middle of the flight, you will move to the seat on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and a seat at the end of the row for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can see the sights. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting places so everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.
**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans. Our captain checks the weather on the morning of the flight and chooses the best direction for clear views.
**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica because of environmental reasons. If you want to see wildlife, you need to join a boat tour.
**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring all cameras. We also have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Little Chefs**
A group of children aged ten to fifteen spend their Saturdays learning to cook. Many children want to join, so there is a waiting list of 30 kids. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food.
Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together."
Flora is twelve years old. She has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby instead of staying home on weekends. At first, I didn't want to come, but now I am very happy I did."
Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, but the kitchen can be messy when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, the children will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**Winter Driving**
Winter can be dangerous for driving. It is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be under the melting snow, which can make you lose control of your car. A car coming towards you might slide on the road.
**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. If you move the car too quickly, it can be hard to control. When you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or go faster, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive carefully so you do not spill it.
**Rule Number Two** is to pay attention to what might happen. If there is a lot of ice, look further down the road. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. 
In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

Craigie Aitchison**
Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. In art school, he found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art. He became interested in early Italian artists, and this can be seen in some of his paintings. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the bright light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. 
Aitchison painted colors in layers, from light to dark. He said, "It's a secret - because I don't know what will happen." He does not start with a plan for the colors. He believes anyone can use colors because you can buy them. He just pays attention to how colors look next to each other. 
Unlike some artists, Aitchison does not make drawings before he paints. He thinks that if he draws first, he might get bored and not finish the painting. He often changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes to paint people who do not want to see their pictures while he is painting. He says, "If they are worried and want to look, I can't paint."
Since he moved to London, Aitchison has not felt part of the Scottish art scene. He does not want to follow any tradition; he just paints in his own way. Still, his work inspires young British painters.

'Rock Band'**
Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we did not want to buy it because of the noise. Ben said, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games. It will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the family and the neighbors when you play."
That was just the start. Drums are hard to move, so Ben's friends came to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for many hours each week, our house is loud with their music and singing. 
At least Ben's hobby is good for our health. When the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. I must say, even if their music is a little strange, they are a nice and polite group of young men. I cannot say if they are good musicians, but they play often in local clubs for young people.
Our main worry is that they will not spend enough time on their school work because of music. So far, this has not happened. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is sure: Ben was right. Playing music has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

Atlantic College**
Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. This college helps young people get experience outside the classroom and study for their exams. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from many countries. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities, like helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.
One good thing about Atlantic College is that students come from different backgrounds and countries. Many students cannot pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, so there are grants available. About a quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only go to the college because they get help from the government.
Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for helping young people understand each other. You learn to live with people and respect them, even if you don’t like them. During the summer, my mother was surprised that I argued less with my sister."
In short, Atlantic College gives its students a great education with methods that really work.

Being an Older Student**
I am 32 years old, and I just finished my first year at university. I go to classes regularly, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. 
Before, I worked as a secretary. I earned good money, but I was bored because my job was easy. I felt sad because I thought I was stuck in that job. I saw students at the local university who looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to feel that way too.
Now that I am a student, I find it hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. 
But I am happy to study because I know I need a good qualification to get a good job, and that is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer to spend my weekends reading books instead of going to parties. I also enjoy the benefits of being a student, like long holidays and discounts for the theatre and cinema.
Sometimes I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that going back to school at this age is a good choice.

Henry Ford**
Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen years old, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong and light steel to make cars that were cheap for regular people to buy. 
In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant there were fewer choices. Henry Ford said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it is black."
